TEXT.English: As with "Emperor's Hand," Praetorian warrior-priests draw threads of fate around the city and shield it from crime, disorder, and chaos. But this time the threads are drawn so tight as to throttle the city. Enemies of Patria often cannot even enter. But even they city's citizens find the restrictions oppressive. The difference between devotion to the Empire and obsessive insanity becomes small. The difference between treason and the True Death, nonexistent.

TEXT.German: Welchen Wert hat durch Feuer gewonnenes Land? Welches Reich kann auf verbrannten Feldern und abgeholzten Wäldern errichtet werden? Dämonische Bündnisse sind beiderseits kurzsichtig. Die einzig wahre Stärke liegt in Schöpfung und Ordnung. - Agadean, Akolyt der Weisung

TEXT.English: [TAB]Slavery is a system whereby some people are judged far inferior to others and are treated as objects or possessions, with no more rights than those afforded to chairs or cattle. Slavery has existed as long as human history, from the earliest primitive times to the enlightened days of Greece and Rome and right up until today. Sometimes convicted criminals were made into slaves. Sometimes captured enemies of the state were enslaved. Sometimes people of a specific race or coloration were enslaved. In some civilizations a person could purchase their freedom or were allotted it after being enslaved for a specific period of time. [PARAGRAPH:2]The advantage of slavery is that it allows people to be forced to do jobs that they would otherwise refuse to do without adequate compensation. Cheap labor results in concentration of wealth and thus the creation of great buildings and temples or the maintenance of large professional armies. Aside from its basic moral repugnance, the disadvantages of slavery are numerous: it corrupts both slave and master, it badly underutilizes the intelligence and creativity of the subject people, and it almost inevitably leads to revolts and internal strife.
TEXT.French: [TAB]L'esclavagisme est un système par lequel une catégorie de gens est considérée comme très inférieure. Ces derniers sont traités comme des objets ou des biens, et n'ont aucun droit si ce n'est ceux accordés aux chaises ou au bétail. L'esclavage est aussi vieux que l'humanité ; il était déjà présent dans les civilisations primitives, était pratiqué dans la Grèce et la Rome antiques, et perdure encore aujourd'hui. Les gens réduits en esclavage étaient les criminels, les ennemis vaincus, ou les gens de telle ou telle origine. Dans certaines civilisations, les individus pouvaient racheter leur liberté, ou la récupéraient automatiquement après un certain de temps. [PARAGRAPH:2]L'avantage de l'esclavage est qu'il permet de forcer des gens à accomplir certaines tâches qu'ils auraient sinon refusées de faire sans être correctement rémunérés. Cette main-d'oeuvre bon marché permet de concentrer la richesse et de créer de somptueux bâtiments et lieux de culte ou d'entretenir de vastes armées. En plus d'être moralement répugnant, l'esclavage a de nombreux inconvénients : il corrompt autant le maître que l'esclave, il sous-exploite l'intelligence et la créativité des individus soumis, et conduit presque inévitablement à la révolte et aux conflits internes.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff "Sklaverei" beschreibt ein System, in dem Menschen als minderwertig betrachtet werden und kaum mehr Rechte als ein Stuhl oder ein Stück Vieh genießen. Die Sklaverei ist so alt wie die Menschheit selbst. Hielten sich zunächst primitive Stämme Sklaven, blühte bald auch im aufgeklärten Griechenland und im antiken Rom der Sklavenhandel. Sklaven waren in der Regel verurteilte Verbrecher, Kriegsgefangene, Angehörige anderer Völker oder Menschen einer bestimmten Hautfarbe. In einigen Kulturen konnte sich ein Sklave freikaufen oder wurde von seinem Herrn freigelassen. [PARAGRAPH:2]Der Vorteil der Sklaverei liegt auf der Hand: Sklaven sind billige Arbeitskräfte, die entscheidend zum Wohlstand ihrer Herren beitrugen. Letztere waren dadurch in der Lage, gewaltige Tempel zu errichten oder stehende Heere zu unterhalten. Abgesehen vom moralischen Aspekt hat die Sklaverei allerdings einen entscheidenden Nachteil: Sie führt fast immer zu inneren Spannungen und Aufständen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Lo Schiavismo è un sistema sociale fondato in buona parte sulla schiavitù. La schiavitù, storicamente, è la condizione per cui un individuo perde tutti i diritti di persona libera e diventa proprietà di un altro individuo. Il proprietario di uno schiavo aveva diritto di vita e di morte su di esso e sulla sua famiglia, e aveva diritto a sfruttarne il lavoro senza fornire nessun compenso per esso. Spesso il costo per il lavoro degli schiavi era limitato al necessario per la loro sopravvivenza. Uno schiavo poteva nascere in questa condizione, se figlio di schiavi, oppure poteva perdere la libertà in determinate situazioni, la più comune delle quali era la cattura in guerra.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lo schiavismo era ampiamente praticato ed accettato nella gran parte delle civiltà antiche, ed era regolato dalle leggi e dalle consuetudini come ogni altra pratica economica. Tra le antiche civiltà, quella romana ha rappresentato il culmine delle società schiavistiche, nelle quali il lavoro degli schiavi rappresentava una componente essenziale dell'economia. Anche l'antica Grecia basava gran parte della sua economia sugli schiavi, tanto è vero che ad Atene per lunghi periodi ci sono stati più schiavi che uomini liberi.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El esclavismo es un sistema en el que parte de la población, considerada inferior al resto y despojada de sus derechos, recibe un tratamiento equiparable al del ganado o las posesiones materiales. La esclavitud ha existido durante toda la historia: desde los tiempos más primitivos hasta nuestros días, pasando por la luminosa época de Roma y Grecia. A veces, los criminales convictos eran condenados a la esclavitud. Otras, los enemigos del estado capturados sufrían este destino. Y otras, lo sufría la gente de una raza o un color concretos. En algunas civilizaciones, una persona podía comprar su libertad, o la recibía tras un periodo de esclavitud estipulado. [PARAGRAPH:2]La ventaja del sistema esclavista es que a los esclavos se les pueden imponer trabajos que cualquier persona se negaría a hacer sin recibir una compensación adecuada. La mano de obra barata permite la concentración de capital y, consecuentemente, la creación de grandes edificios y templos, o el mantenimiento de grandes ejércitos profesionales. Aparte de los más evidentes aspectos morales, las desventajas del esclavismo son numerosas: corrompe al esclavo y al amo, derrocha terriblemente la inteligencia y creatividad de los esclavos y acaba desembocando casi inevitablemente en revueltas y conflictos civiles.

Abgesehen vom moralischen Aspekt hat die Sklaverei allerdings einen entscheidenden Nachteil: Sie führt fast immer zu inneren Spannungen und Aufständen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Lo Schiavismo è un sistema sociale fondato in buona parte sulla schiavitù. La schiavitù, storicamente, è la condizione per cui un individuo perde tutti i diritti di persona libera e diventa proprietà di un altro individuo. Il proprietario di uno schiavo aveva diritto di vita e di morte su di esso e sulla sua famiglia, e aveva diritto a sfruttarne il lavoro senza fornire nessun compenso per esso. Spesso il costo per il lavoro degli schiavi era limitato al necessario per la loro sopravvivenza. Uno schiavo poteva nascere in questa condizione, se figlio di schiavi, oppure poteva perdere la libertà in determinate situazioni, la più comune delle quali era la cattura in guerra.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lo schiavismo era ampiamente praticato ed accettato nella gran parte delle civiltà antiche, ed era regolato dalle leggi e dalle consuetudini come ogni altra pratica economica. Tra le antiche civiltà, quella romana ha rappresentato il culmine delle società schiavistiche, nelle quali il lavoro degli schiavi rappresentava una componente essenziale dell'economia. Anche l'antica Grecia basava gran parte della sua economia sugli schiavi, tanto è vero che ad Atene per lunghi periodi ci sono stati più schiavi che uomini liberi.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El esclavismo es un sistema en el que parte de la población, considerada inferior al resto y despojada de sus derechos, recibe un tratamiento equiparable al del ganado o las posesiones materiales. La esclavitud ha existido durante toda la historia: desde los tiempos más primitivos hasta nuestros días, pasando por la luminosa época de Roma y Grecia. A veces, los criminales convictos eran condenados a la esclavitud. Otras, los enemigos del estado capturados sufrían este destino. Y otras, lo sufría la gente de una raza o un color concretos. En algunas civilizaciones, una persona podía comprar su libertad, o la recibía tras un periodo de esclavitud estipulado. [PARAGRAPH:2]La ventaja del sistema esclavista es que a los esclavos se les pueden imponer trabajos que cualquier persona se negaría a hacer sin recibir una compensación adecuada. La mano de obra barata permite la concentración de capital y, consecuentemente, la creación de grandes edificios y templos, o el mantenimiento de grandes ejércitos profesionales. Aparte de los más evidentes aspectos morales, las desventajas del esclavismo son numerosas: corrompe al esclavo y al amo, derrocha terriblemente la inteligencia y creatividad de los esclavos y acaba desembocando casi inevitablemente en revueltas y conflictos civiles.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Slavery is a system whereby some people are judged far inferior to others and are treated as objects or possessions, with no more rights than those afforded to chairs or cattle. Slavery has existed as long as human history, from the earliest primitive times to the enlightened days of Greece and Rome and right up until today. Sometimes convicted criminals were made into slaves. Sometimes captured enemies of the state were enslaved. Sometimes people of a specific race or coloration were enslaved. In some civilizations a person could purchase their freedom or were allotted it after being enslaved for a specific period of time. [PARAGRAPH:2]The advantage of slavery is that it allows people to be forced to do jobs that they would otherwise refuse to do without adequate compensation. Cheap labor results in concentration of wealth and thus the creation of great buildings and temples or the maintenance of large professional armies. Aside from its basic moral repugnance, the disadvantages of slavery are numerous: it corrupts both slave and master, it badly underutilizes the intelligence and creativity of the subject people, and it almost inevitably leads to revolts and internal strife.
TEXT.French: [TAB]L'esclavagisme est un système par lequel une catégorie de gens est considérée comme très inférieure. Ces derniers sont traités comme des objets ou des biens, et n'ont aucun droit si ce n'est ceux accordés aux chaises ou au bétail. L'esclavage est aussi vieux que l'humanité ; il était déjà présent dans les civilisations primitives, était pratiqué dans la Grèce et la Rome antiques, et perdure encore aujourd'hui. Les gens réduits en esclavage étaient les criminels, les ennemis vaincus, ou les gens de telle ou telle origine. Dans certaines civilisations, les individus pouvaient racheter leur liberté, ou la récupéraient automatiquement après un certain de temps. [PARAGRAPH:2]L'avantage de l'esclavage est qu'il permet de forcer des gens à accomplir certaines tâches qu'ils auraient sinon refusées de faire sans être correctement rémunérés. Cette main-d'oeuvre bon marché permet de concentrer la richesse et de créer de somptueux bâtiments et lieux de culte ou d'entretenir de vastes armées. En plus d'être moralement répugnant, l'esclavage a de nombreux inconvénients : il corrompt autant le maître que l'esclave, il sous-exploite l'intelligence et la créativité des individus soumis, et conduit presque inévitablement à la révolte et aux conflits internes.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff "Sklaverei" beschreibt ein System, in dem Menschen als minderwertig betrachtet werden und kaum mehr Rechte als ein Stuhl oder ein Stück Vieh genießen. Die Sklaverei ist so alt wie die Menschheit selbst. Hielten sich zunächst primitive Stämme Sklaven, blühte bald auch im aufgeklärten Griechenland und im antiken Rom der Sklavenhandel. Sklaven waren in der Regel verurteilte Verbrecher, Kriegsgefangene, Angehörige anderer Völker oder Menschen einer bestimmten Hautfarbe. In einigen Kulturen konnte sich ein Sklave freikaufen oder wurde von seinem Herrn freigelassen. [PARAGRAPH:2]Der Vorteil der Sklaverei liegt auf der Hand: Sklaven sind billige Arbeitskräfte, die entscheidend zum Wohlstand ihrer Herren beitrugen. TEXT.English: [NEWLINE]If their is one thing a man get's sick of. It's the near constant clattering of bone on bone. Not that reusing your fallen foes as expendable soldiers was a bad idea. But it lacked a certain, class. Gerin sat on the hill carving symbols into the earth. Afterwards he double checked all the reagents, then began to speak. [NEWLINE]The land seemed to darken slightly as he intoned the final words, and then the shadow coalesced into one being. The shade seemed to rise out of the ground and silently inclined it's head in obedience. The necromancer turned to the encampment in the valley below and smiled. So what if one lead to another, No matter how they died. He always had his in the end.

TEXT.English: He didn't know how much further he could run. His son clung to his back, exhausted and unable to move himself. They had already lost a 10th of their number to the grueling chase. [NEWLINE]When the Sheiam attacked the knights had laid down their lives to save them, and now that sacrifice wasn't going to matter anymore. As the group finally came to a halt as all hope left them. [NEWLINE]The old man rested on his staff and looked back. The enemy was chasing them still, just as fast as ever, just as deadly. He shook his head, then turned toward the approaching hoard and as he lifted his staff into the air, it outshone the sun itself.

TEXT.English:
Two men, one young, tall, and handsome, the other short, fat, and balding, sat across from each other on the patio of Hexam's finest pub. The place's other patrons, an old man who sat watching the setting sun, two women who sat giggling and exchanging flirtations, and one of the best looking whores Hexam had ever seen, paid them no mind. The Horned Rooster's decorations were tastefully gaudy (insofar as such a thing could exist) and its drinks generally had no more effects than those advertised. Its patio overlooked the finest beach in the Balseraph Empire. But the two sitting at a table by the patio's edge had come together to do more than contemplate the oceans, or ogle those on its beach.
The younger said, "the problem is simply that nobody has a firm definition of what an illusion is. Any time somebody offers a firm definition, they discover that something they believed was real is, by their own definition, an illusion. Or confess that my creations are not illusions. If you don't believe me, Ozziel, then try me." The elder, Ozziel, said "very well, Nojah. An illusion is something which is not real, but takes on the appearance of being real." Nojah laughed, and said, "oh, come. I'd expected better of you! Define real, then!" Ozziel sighed and looked into his glass. He'd not had anything to drink but strawberry wine, and in small amounts, as he'd been warned dealing with Nojah would test one's wits to their very ends. Ozziel said, "something is real if it has a distinct effect upon the world around it, and is effected by the world around it." Nojah said, "then say I create an illusory Balor, and set it loose amongst some Bannor. Would the creature not have a 'distinct effect?' And I am perfectly capable of enchanting it to bleed should it meet steel, thus fulfilling the requirement that it be effected by the world around it."
Ozziel nodded his assent. "Very well, Nojah," he said. "You illusions can effect the senses of sight, sound, and smell. But what of touch and taste? Can you deceive those as well?" With a flick of his wrist, Nojah summoned an apple and tossed it to Ozziel. He caught it; it flickered briefly, and Ozziel knew that was Nojah demonstrating that, despite appearances, the apple he held was nothing more than the product of his senses being deceived. Ozziel tossed it from hand to hand, impressed by the precision of the illusion, before taking a bite. "It tastes like apple cider," he exclaimed, and greedily devoured it. He was about to dispose of the core when it burst into flame; he shrieked in terror and clutched his hand, which throbbed with pain, but was unmarked. Nojah snapped his fingers, and the taste in his mouth, the feeling of fullness in his stomach, and the pain in his hand, all vanished without a trace.
Ozziel stared, dumbfounded, while Nojah merely smiled. He said, "my dear Ozziel, you underestimate me. Or perhaps overestimate the peoples of Erebus. Humanity is nothing more than the senses with which we take in information, and the mind which reacts to, yet is molded by, that information. I cannot create physical food, but I can turn the most drab of foods into a delicious treat. Or trick the starving into thinking their bellies are full even as they fall into Arwan's arms. I can bring pleasure and pain, or convince people that one is the other. I can make a slave shriek with joy at every lash of the whip... or, if I prefer, make the slave driver feel every blow he places upon his charges." Nojah then pointed to the pretty whore, saying, "what do you make of her?" Ozziel said, "Let me guess, she's an illusion?" Nojah said, "maybe. She might also be an ugly whore who I have given the appearance of a pretty one. Or precisely what she appears to be? You see, by controlling the information granted to your senses, I may as well have control over all of reality. How will you be able to tell the difference between the falsehoods I feed your mind, and what you deem 'reality,' which might well simply be falsehoods fed you by another?" Ozziel said, "by cheating."
The old man, hearing the signal, released the incantation he had prepared earlier. There was a great burst of light; when it faded, everything had changed. The wine in Ozziel's cup had turned to cheap, watered down rum, and the paint of the Horned Rooster had become faded. The whore's true form turned out to be an old, gnarled wench, and she glared with raw hatred at the one who had dispelled the illusion about her. The two women who had been flirting were both revealed to be men; they stared at each other with shock and disgust before quickly packing and leaving, red-faced. Nojah, although still younger and more handsome than Ozziel had expected, was now stark naked. He sighed, waved his illusory clothes back on, and said, "well played. But frankly, you have merely dodged the points I was trying to make about reality and the senses. Had you not had that friend of yours... how did you talk him into it, anyways?" Ozziel said, "He wanted a chance to preach to the Balseraphs, and I said I'd help him around town if he'd do that little magic trick. But about that point about reality and the senses; yes, I suppose there are a lot of illusions in the world. Others may disagree, but I've always felt all of society is nothing but a shared illusion; I suppose all we can do is trust our senses and our hearts." Nojah said, "indeed. Hearts always have been slightly harder to manipulate than senses," he said, as he left. "Wait, only slightly harder?" Ozziel muttered, worried, as he watched the Illusionist disappear into the crowds of Hexam.

The wine in Ozziel's cup had turned to cheap, watered down rum, and the paint of the Horned Rooster had become faded. The whore's true form turned out to be an old, gnarled wench, and she glared with raw hatred at the one who had dispelled the illusion about her. The two women who had been flirting were both revealed to be men; they stared at each other with shock and disgust before quickly packing and leaving, red-faced. Nojah, although still younger and more handsome than Ozziel had expected, was now stark naked. He sighed, waved his illusory clothes back on, and said, "well played. But frankly, you have merely dodged the points I was trying to make about reality and the senses. Had you not had that friend of yours... how did you talk him into it, anyways?" Ozziel said, "He wanted a chance to preach to the Balseraphs, and I said I'd help him around town if he'd do that little magic trick. But about that point about reality and the senses; yes, I suppose there are a lot of illusions in the world. Others may disagree, but I've always felt all of society is nothing but a shared illusion; I suppose all we can do is trust our senses and our hearts." Nojah said, "indeed. Hearts always have been slightly harder to manipulate than senses," he said, as he left. "Wait, only slightly harder?" Ozziel muttered, worried, as he watched the Illusionist disappear into the crowds of Hexam.
TEXT.German:
Two men, one young, tall, and handsome, the other short, fat, and balding, sat across from each other on the patio of Hexam's finest pub. The place's other patrons, an old man who sat watching the setting sun, two women who sat giggling and exchanging flirtations, and one of the best looking whores Hexam had ever seen, paid them no mind. The Horned Rooster's decorations were tastefully gaudy (insofar as such a thing could exist) and its drinks generally had no more effects than those advertised. Its patio overlooked the finest beach in the Balseraph Empire. But the two sitting at a table by the patio's edge had come together to do more than contemplate the oceans, or ogle those on its beach.
The younger said, "the problem is simply that nobody has a firm definition of what an illusion is. Any time somebody offers a firm definition, they discover that something they believed was real is, by their own definition, an illusion. Or confess that my creations are not illusions. If you don't believe me, Ozziel, then try me." The elder, Ozziel, said "very well, Nojah. An illusion is something which is not real, but takes on the appearance of being real." Nojah laughed, and said, "oh, come. I'd expected better of you! Define real, then!" Ozziel sighed and looked into his glass. He'd not had anything to drink but strawberry wine, and in small amounts, as he'd been warned dealing with Nojah would test one's wits to their very ends. Ozziel said, "something is real if it has a distinct effect upon the world around it, and is effected by the world around it." Nojah said, "then say I create an illusory Balor, and set it loose amongst some Bannor. Would the creature not have a 'distinct effect?' And I am perfectly capable of enchanting it to bleed should it meet steel, thus fulfilling the requirement that it be effected by the world around it."
Ozziel nodded his assent. "Very well, Nojah," he said. "You illusions can effect the senses of sight, sound, and smell. But what of touch and taste? Can you deceive those as well?" With a flick of his wrist, Nojah summoned an apple and tossed it to Ozziel. He caught it; it flickered briefly, and Ozziel knew that was Nojah demonstrating that, despite appearances, the apple he held was nothing more than the product of his senses being deceived. Ozziel tossed it from hand to hand, impressed by the precision of the illusion, before taking a bite. "It tastes like apple cider," he exclaimed, and greedily devoured it. He was about to dispose of the core when it burst into flame; he shrieked in terror and clutched his hand, which throbbed with pain, but was unmarked. Nojah snapped his fingers, and the taste in his mouth, the feeling of fullness in his stomach, and the pain in his hand, all vanished without a trace.
Ozziel stared, dumbfounded, while Nojah merely smiled. He said, "my dear Ozziel, you underestimate me. Or perhaps overestimate the peoples of Erebus. Humanity is nothing more than the senses with which we take in information, and the mind which reacts to, yet is molded by, that information. I cannot create physical food, but I can turn the most drab of foods into a delicious treat. Or trick the starving into thinking their bellies are full even as they fall into Arwan's arms. I can bring pleasure and pain, or convince people that one is the other. I can make a slave shriek with joy at every lash of the whip... or, if I prefer, make the slave driver feel every blow he places upon his charges." Nojah then pointed to the pretty whore, saying, "what do you make of her?" Ozziel said, "Let me guess, she's an illusion?" Nojah said, "maybe. She might also be an ugly whore who I have given the appearance of a pretty one. Or precisely what she appears to be? You see, by controlling the information granted to your senses, I may as well have control over all of reality. How will you be able to tell the difference between the falsehoods I feed your mind, and what you deem 'reality,' which might well simply be falsehoods fed you by another?" Ozziel said, "by cheating."

TEXT.English: from the Achronical Magazine:[PARAGRAPH:1]Scouts are almost always eaten alive by giant spiders. Luckily for them, they are sometimes eaten by wild animals - like canines and great cats - who prefer to kill their prey first. This is all quite ironic as scouts are usually send out by evil overlords to catch said wild animals. It was heard that Calabim sages were trying to streamline this process by cutting scouts into little pieces and feedung them directly to the animals. Asked for a statement by Achronical Magazine Calabim officials said, that the rationale behind this project was of peaceful nature as its goal was to aquire wild animals for circuses to please the citizens. But the project was halted anyway, because it only lured dangerous animals to Calabim feeding pits. Furthermore a somewhat pale looking Calabim spokes person pointed out that no death mana was used in the process.

TEXT.English: The Malakim cannot build roads, they never found a need for it they move through the desert as swiftly as other people move on roads wherever the desert reaches their caravans can go. So desert tiles count as basic roads for resource transport, trade routes and army movement. Also in their territory the desert automatically spreads.

TEXT.English:
"How does one capture the essence of a people on canvas?" Shemun pointed to a series of paintings leaning against the wall of the college entryhall. All recent works of himself, all showing either great vistas of desert or the great malakim trading city of Timberling. "I spent 2 years among the desert people Cashiel and tried to commit my impressions to canvas and in many respects I succeeded. Here you can see the hustle and bustle of the great basar of Timberling with it´s multitude of traders from all over Erebus bartering for both mundane and exotic goods. The painting over there shows the twin harbours of the city, the always busy trade harbor with it´s dozens of craft competing for the best anchorage and the war harbour which only opens its floodgates in times of war. On this one you can see the sun reflecting of the main barracks of the radiant guard and the entrance to the great hall of empyrean with its lavish fountains and beautiful marble statues. But what really defines the desert people I could not paint. I only once caught a glimpse of it when I was visiting an oasis famed for it´s incredibly sweet dates. Imagine you are riding on a docile camel in the sweltering heat of the late afternoon desert. Your mouth is dry and you are looking forward to the caravanserei in which you will spend the night and a cool jug of sweet wine. Then you become aware of a rumbling sound slowly becoming louder. You search the horizons for Thunderclouds. There! You find it. It is low to the ground and quickly coming closer, the continuous sound of thunder steadily growing louder. You try to make sense of the cloud seemingly coming right at you at enormous speed and then a few seconds before it envelops you you can see the riders in sand coloured robes on their camels. Then all is chaos and you can see only sand, heavily armed riders and their camels, the dust makes you blink and the sand invades your clothes your mouth and your nose. All you can do is pray that no one hits you as you sit there on your immobile camel and the raiders pass by in front and behind. And then as suddendly as they appeared they dissapear behind the next dune and all that remains is that rumbling sound slowly growing fainter and a feeling of profound gratefulness that you were not their target today."
-Shemun, Dural Master Painter to a Colleague

TEXT.English:
"Believe me lad you don´t want to go to one of those ancient elven forests." Shamun looked at the old mercenary who had sat down opposite him questioningly. "You don´t wanna go there lad cause it won´t be like in the songs and pictures for you. I know the elves write poems and paint pictures that all show how beautiful and peaceful their forests are and those songs and pictures make you wanna go there yourself, paint a picture yourself, feel the serenity and peace, write a poem about it, maybe get lucky with a nymph or dryad while you are there. All nice cozy and safe yes?"
The old mercenary took a long swig from his jug and set it down with a sigh, then he continued in a quieter voice. "You lad will find none of those things there. I grant you there probably is harmony, peace, unicorns and rainbows and all kinds of other nice stuff there but not for the likes of you and me. We don´t belong there. You´d be an intruder and the forest would make you feel it. When you walk the forest you will always feel like distubing the order of the place. When you see small beasts they will run and hide. When you hear birdsong you will know they are talking about you telling the others you are coming. And should you actually manage to find something like a unicorn you should consider yourself lucky if it doesn´t run you through on the spot.
But the worst.... the worst are the trees themselves. Even if you learn to be careful in there in time you have to sleep lad. And in there it is quite possible to bed your head down on solid ground only to wake up hours later and find roots strangling you. Don´t go there lad, don´t intrude, just stay in the city and paint what your imagination shows you. It´ll be closer to what the forests are for those who live in them and it´ll be much safer for you."
-Advice given to Shemun, Dural Master Painter by Verain a Grigori Mercenary

TEXT.English:
"Yes you are right on first glance it seems odd, maybe even a little hypocritical of me, but let me explain. Elijah Arnauld a very wealthy Calabim governor and holder of the slave trade monopoly within the Calabim nation heard of the portrait I did of Captain Ostanes the famous Hippus mercenary captain. Supposedly he even travelled here incognito to see the painting in our art museum and he resolved that he would have one made of himself. So he sent me letter after letter petitioning me to visit his estates and paint him in oil. He even went so far as to suggest background pose and composition to me. I of course refused not only because I was concerned for my safety but also because I still believe myself to posess some artistic integrity. That did not stop him however and when his petitions did not bear fruit he started to threaten first me and then people close to me.
Finally one of my students stopped showing up for his lessons and a few days later I got a letter telling me to come to Nubia to buy my student back for the very low price of one small portrait. I was afraid of course and did not want to go. I would like to tell you that seeing that my students life was in danger I immediatly made travel arrangements, but I did not. I am not a hero I am a painter. But the students family was a powerful one and they began to apply pressure to for me to go and accept the deal. Finally it got so bad here, that I thought Nubia could not be that much worse and I went. I was terribly wrong but that is a tale for another time.
I met Elijah Arnauld in his slave pens where he was sparring with my student always drawing a little blood. From the scarring he must have been doing this ever since he kidnapped my pupil and I am sure had I not come someday my pupil would have died as the consequence of a tragic "mistake". We struck a deal then. I would paint his likeness in any garment and pose I desired and he would let my student go upon completion of the painting. It took me 2 months in the slavepens of Nubia where he insisted on holding our session to capture his likeness on canvas. The flawless features and alabaster skin without a single blemish were complete in the first weeks the rest of the time I kept working on the details.
If you look closely you can see his writhing victims in the way his robe falls. You can see their tormented faces in the background in the bark of the trees and in the clouds overhead. It took me two months to capture all the suffering I could that surrounded him. Then I declared the picture finished and showed it to him. To my astonishment he was delighted with the painting. And seeing my astonishment he told me in that eerily quiet musical voice of his: "Ultimate beauty my dear genius can only be made tangible by contrasting it with ultimate horror." Well I podered this a long time and I think he was right. That is why I placed his portrait next to the painting of Saint Lessa the Leper."
-Shemun, Dural Master Painter

-Shemun, Dural Master Painter
TEXT.German:
"Yes you are right on first glance it seems odd, maybe even a little hypocritical of me, but let me explain. Elijah Arnauld a very wealthy Calabim governor and holder of the slave trade monopoly within the Calabim nation heard of the portrait I did of Captain Ostanes the famous Hippus mercenary captain. Supposedly he even travelled here incognito to see the painting in our art museum and he resolved that he would have one made of himself. So he sent me letter after letter petitioning me to visit his estates and paint him in oil. He even went so far as to suggest background pose and composition to me. I of course refused not only because I was concerned for my safety but also because I still believe myself to posess some artistic integrity. That did not stop him however and when his petitions did not bear fruit he started to threaten first me and then people close to me.
Finally one of my students stopped showing up for his lessons and a few days later I got a letter telling me to come to Nubia to buy my student back for the very low price of one small portrait. I was afraid of course and did not want to go. I would like to tell you that seeing that my students life was in danger I immediatly made travel arrangements, but I did not. I am not a hero I am a painter. But the students family was a powerful one and they began to apply pressure to for me to go and accept the deal. Finally it got so bad here, that I thought Nubia could not be that much worse and I went. I was terribly wrong but that is a tale for another time.
I met Elijah Arnauld in his slave pens where he was sparring with my student always drawing a little blood. From the scarring he must have been doing this ever since he kidnapped my pupil and I am sure had I not come someday my pupil would have died as the consequence of a tragic "mistake". We struck a deal then. I would paint his likeness in any garment and pose I desired and he would let my student go upon completion of the painting. It took me 2 months in the slavepens of Nubia where he insisted on holding our session to capture his likeness on canvas. TEXT.English:
Verlain looked at the conscripts and farmboys that had been put under his command. Faces to young to shave and too old for a full set of teeth looked back exited and nervous. His small unit had been stationed about 200 yards behind the main battle line that consisted mainly of Bannor heavy infantry interspersed with groups of elven sword-dancers. At the flanks of the armies formation were large units of elven longbowmen, like furled wings hidden behind the main body but ready to swoop out as soon as the enemy was in sight. But closest to him and his primary responsibilty were the Bannor priests and Elven mages standing by to support the infantry with magic and miracles. His small unit like a few others had been given the task of protecting the spellcasters from dwarfen stragglers that might break through the main line.
Aaron the lord who had hired him came riding over to Verlain just as the first dwarven columns came in sight in the mouth of the pass. Line after line of heavily armored and armed dwarves marched in orderly fashion and accompanied by the sound of drums and blowpipes began to form in battle array facing the allied army positioned on the top of a gentle rise. "How are my boys Verlain?" Lord Aaron asked him gaily. "Nervous and a bit too excited my lord, i fear some of them will be severly disappointed when they discover that war is more about pain and blood then about honor and glory. But else they seem steady." Verlain keept looking at the dwarven army while he talked with his employer and saw a great horde of big fat boars being herded in the woods that framed the valley. "Today should not be that bad my gloomy friend. The dwarves have only infantry and some war machines, which they can´t deploy due to the rugged terrain. Our archers and mages will thin out their charge and then our infantry will hack the survivors to bits. We will eat those big fat boars at the victory feast tonight Verlain." Aaron said inclinig his head towards the boars and shepards entering the woods.
The battle began as planned the dwarves advancing uphill, the archers peppering them with arrows and Verlain kept close to the mages calling down lightning on the dwarven ranks. Verlain kept his boys in loose formation a couple score yards behind the battle line close to the mages and priests. But when the dwarves had covered half the distance towards the defenders three long clear horncalls rang out from the dwarfen lines. Suddendly the fringes of the forests framing the valley were no longer empty. Hundreds of those gigantic boars the dwarves had herded into the trees charged right for the archers and the priests and spellcasters and each of those boars carried a dwarf. A few yards before they clashed into the armies flanks the boars slowed down for a few paces and their riders jumped off charging on behind the boars. Even while frantically reorganizing his men Verlain saw dwarf and boar mercilessly gutting file after file of archers. The Boar riders coming for the mages had were now riding through a hastiliy conjured Thunderstorm that did not seem to slow them much and Verlain made ready to meet their charge. Then a sudden pain exploded in his temple and he fell to the ground loosing consciousness.
He woke to a blinding headache and the smell of roasted boar. A leather clad, dark bearded and rather dirty dwarf stared into his eyes. "Glad am you fine" he said in atrocious common. His speech guttural and thick. "Dead man no ransom. But you fine armour be great commander yes?" Verlain grunted and pain shot through his head again then he tried to speak "I am no great commander but I have some savings. You will get your ransom." The dwarf grinned: "That good enough. You hungry? Killed my riding beast in battle but taste good yes? Not so fine as horse for riding, not so fast, perhaps not so beautiful." The dwarf grinned. "But easy hiding and much better tasting yes?"
- The Battle of Silvervale

TEXT.English:
So what is the key to winning a battle by magical means? Sure we all know how to invoke fire upon our enemies. We are all familiar with the forces of air and lightning. But all the fire we can call will avail us little if the enemy is hidden behind stout fortress walls and lightning from the skies won´t bother dwarves hiding in caves much. I therefore propose a different approach. In casting our combat spells we select certain properties of Erebus and exert our will to concentrate those properties on the point of effect. When casting a fireball spell for example we concentrate a lot of heat energy in a single place. But, all that energy does not come from within us. It can not. Not even the most powerful archmage would be able to keep that much power inside of him for a significant amount of time. So we reach out along the threads of the fabric of reality to gather the power we need and relocate some small threads from here and there to achieve our desired effect.
I now propose an inverted approach. With a comparable amount of effort we should be able to reach out along the fabric and weaken not just the threads corresponding to certain elements but simply all the threads of reality in a certain place. Doing that should create a temporary instability in the veil that seperates our world from the the realms of deamons and angels. Such an instability would, so I believe, lead to a ripple effect spreading outwards along the strongest ley lines present in the area and distribute anything standing close to the instabilty to random locations in the immediate vicinity. And dear collegues this would not be a gentle means of relocation.
While I believe that great care must be taken not to create a permanent doorway thusly allowing beings outside of our reality to step through, it would allow us to greatly disatvantage any well dug in defender and make them vulnerable to elimination by more direct applications of combat wizardry.
- research proposal by Leoris Coldwell, Amurite Wizard

Such an instability would, so I believe, lead to a ripple effect spreading outwards along the strongest ley lines present in the area and distribute anything standing close to the instabilty to random locations in the immediate vicinity. And dear collegues this would not be a gentle means of relocation.
While I believe that great care must be taken not to create a permanent doorway thusly allowing beings outside of our reality to step through, it would allow us to greatly disatvantage any well dug in defender and make them vulnerable to elimination by more direct applications of combat wizardry.
- research proposal by Leoris Coldwell, Amurite Wizard
TEXT.Italian:
So what is the key to winning a battle by magical means? Sure we all know how to invoke fire upon our enemies. We are all familiar with the forces of air and lightning. But all the fire we can call will avail us little if the enemy is hidden behind stout fortress walls and lightning from the skies won´t bother dwarves hiding in caves much. I therefore propose a different approach. In casting our combat spells we select certain properties of Erebus and exert our will to concentrate those properties on the point of effect. When casting a fireball spell for example we concentrate a lot of heat energy in a single place. But, all that energy does not come from within us. It can not. Not even the most powerful archmage would be able to keep that much power inside of him for a significant amount of time. So we reach out along the threads of the fabric of reality to gather the power we need and relocate some small threads from here and there to achieve our desired effect.
I now propose an inverted approach. TEXT.English:
To see the world one must travel it, that much is true. But how to decide what is worth seeing? How to judge if the gain is worth the risk? You could spend many an evening in roadside taverns listening to travellers tales, but most likely you will learn more about the prices of wool and pork in Kwythellar than about the cosmopolitan air of its broad collonaded streets and the dazzling variety its proud walls hold. You can walk the docks talking to sailors just in from their journeys to the Amurite islands. But most likely you will hear more tales, most likely fabricated ones, about enormous sea monsters and magical nights of pleasure, than about the wonders of magically supplemented architecture and the miracles of weather control magic the amurites use so well. You could even visit the barracks and talk to our grizzled veterans, men who have seen many a corner of erebus. You will mostly hear about Ljosalfar women and the wines of the Elohim not about the breathtaking sight of Cahir Abbey its terraced Vineyards and flowergardens filling the whole vista. So how are you to know where to go if you are neither soldier nor trader nor sailor?
Come to our fine art gallery my friend! Here you can see for yourself the majesty of Cahir Abbey, the madness and gaity of a belseraph carneval, the mysterious shadows of the sidar capital of Celo, Doviello hunting rituals and even the torments suffered by the souls of the damned near Dis. And if anything sparks your interest you will know where you need to travel to satisfy your curiosity. This week only we offer tickets for the ridiculously low price of 2 silver per person and children under 8 are free!
-An advertisement for a Dural art gallery

TEXT.English:
The sun was comfortably warm on Sorahs back as she was lying beside Joltuk, one of the best scouts of her small band of Austrin hunters and explorers. " Seems the long winter is truly gone for good." Joltuk grunted as she removed her wolf fur coat. She looked down on her friend since childhood and grinned mischieviously: "Aren´t you supposed to watch their camp and not lust after every bit of flesh you see?" "I can´t help it when you present yourself so appealingly, besides we´ve been watching them for weeks and seen nothing interesting so far." You may not have my ogrish friend but your focus seems somewhat narrow to me. I think they have a lot of promise." "Not their women, they don´t." Sorah grinned: "Since you are useless as a scout today go tell the others to get ready to move." And she started planning her approach.
In the ghostlight of the new dawn they easily penetratet the camps peremiter. While her best archers took up position above the camp those preferring close combat moved to block the main paths. Making contact was always the most dangerous part of her mission and she had learned to be careful. She herself went to the tall Pine growing in the center of the camp, the hulking form of Joltuk spear in hand at her side. There she put her hands on her hips and called in cheerful old patrian: "Good morning fellow people of Erebus. Please do not be alarmed! We come armed but we don´t come to fight. Quite the opposite indeed. We come to discuss the possibility of an alliance. You preserved crafts and traditions from before the age of ice and we would see you flourish in this new age of growth at our side. So let your leader come forward so we may discuss our proposal."
Days later Joltuk and Sorah were leaving, while the rest of the band stayed to protect their new allies. "Well now the real works begins old friend. Go back to request reinforcements and then back here, tame the surrounding area and find other small tribes to supplement their numbers." "And I was so looking forward to spending a summer alone with you at some lakeside." "Well I think we can find some small lake somewhere along our path, and one or two days of rest can´t hurt." Joltuk chuckled. "It´s a deal. Those two days belong to me my dear girl, after that I belong to you again o great commander."

TEXT.English:
Hear my call ancients, eternal guardians of the holy glades!
Your domains have been invaded by axe and by flame, our armies dead our arrows useless our swords drawn in vain. Great pathways were cut and armies of torches come, to burn our homes and we can only run.
Taste the ashes that fall with the rain, those are the trees that won´t bloom again. Drink in the blood that soaks all our land, those are our warriors who failed to defend.
Nothing is left now but you, elder brothers, you have to stir now to save all the others, every birch, pine and oak now still saplings, those who live in their shadows no matter their trappings.
Feel the rage of the defiled!
Feel the pain of the lost!
Feel the fury of the bereaved!
Feel my old friends! Quicken your heartbeats! Tear out your roots! And march!
- Last prayer of Ellianthelain, Elven high priest of Hyll before the great burning

TEXT.English:
"I won´t go! I am not your damn puppet!" Verlain almost shouted. "We are all puppets to one another my dear", the Mage grinned. "Whatever you say you crazy biddy, but I won´t sneak into the forest to see if the elves are still there. One arrow is all that it takes you know." Verlain answered grimly. "Yes you refuse to jump although I pulled your strings." Her makeup that had made her look like a tavern harlot had run in the rain now making her look more like a sad clown. "But I hold only a few of yours so no wonder. Money, flesh, companionship are all puppet strings, but like all strings they are fragile.easily torn if too much pressure is applied. Especially if the other puppeteers jerk the other way." "What other puppeteers? I am a mercenary. I am Grigori. I serve no gods and I work for myself." "Yes puppet sure you do, but why? No sometimes holding some strings of the whole just is not enough." She turned away and started to rummage in her ridiculously large lugagge. "Sometimes if no puppet will do as you ask, it is time to bring a new player on the stage, one fashioned especially for one scene." As she turned back her hair that had been wet and plastered to her head before looked all wiry and was standing off in all directions also her makeup now amplified the impact of her startling blue and green eyes. "Stalker", she said to the small greenclad doll in her hands "You will not refuse my like this nasty big brute of a man has will you?" Verlain looket at the Mage with her doll and saw the doll stare back at him with jealosy and horror. "You will go into the forest over there and see if the nasty elves are still there, will you not my sweet?" The puppet jumped from her hands and started to walk towards the forest, but the mage stopped it. "Before you go take this knife my sweet, so you can defend yourself if they still lurk there." Verlain watched horrified as the small doll ran towards the forest big meat knife in hand while beside him the mage cackled insanely moving her hands in jerky motions.
- Arisa Longhat, Belseraph mage talking to Verlain, Grigori mercenary

TEXT.English:
Shemun stood on a before his scafolld, brush in hand, seemingly forgotten. He had finally gotten permission from the elven court to visit the ancient city of Evermore, and now he stood on a meadow outside the walls. In front of him a pond fed by a sparkling waterfall, the colors of the rainbow dancing between the cascades of water. The spring sun warmed the ground and most of the flowers and trees were in full bloom. He could see deer between the blossoming birch trees and a pair of foxes playing not far away while melodious birdsong filled his ears. He had come here to paint the beauty of the elven realm but he just watched. He did not even see the landscape, all he had eyes for was a beautiful elven maiden walking the meadow. She stopped by every tree she passed leaning her slender bdoy against the bark seemingly listening. From time to time birds would descend from their nests, perch on her shoulder and sing in her ears. Following her closely but never intruding, never startling the brids or other small animals that came to her were a pair of wildcats, seemingly guarding her and occasionally glancing towards Shemun. He had even once seen a unicorn appear far back in the trees also observing the elven woman, but it had been gone so fast he now was no longer sure he had even seen it. And if the activity around her was fascinating she herself was truly captivating. She was undoubtetly beautiful, although not as perfect as some of the Scion women Shemun had seen on his visit to Patria a year before. But she had an aura of vitality and harmony that seemed to radiate out from her making everything she came close too appear more alive. And she had an air of innocence that made his instincts scream to protect her. He was so lost in observing her that he did not even notice that she came towards him until she spoke.
"You should paint this now master artist. You might not get another chance." It took several seconds before Shemun had collected enough conscious thought to stammer an answer. "Wha.... What do you mean by that?" The maiden looked at him and suddendly he saw sadness in her eyes. "The birds tell me of great factories in the lands of the Khazad and the Dural burning scores of trees each day, they say there is nary a tree left there to nest. They also tell me of great fleets of ships being built in the Kingdom of the Lanun, that they fell many a tree only take the strongest of the wood and burn the rest. The badgers tell me that the blight left the fields of the Bannor in the north barren, they say that even field mice find it hard to survive there. And the trees themselves tell me that great clouds of poisons are being carried towards us every summer across the mountains to our west originating from the labs of the Sheaim." Shemus just stared at her while she talked. "When i was still a baby Sheaim pyre-zombies burned the village and the forests my parents lived in. While the Sheaim were slaughtering the villagers I crawled out into the forest and hid from the blaze in a badgers den. The animals cared for me and I learned to talk to them and to the trees before I ever learned to talk to other elves or even humans like yourself. They protected me and now I owe it to them to protect them. We are surrounded by nations that covet our woods, without thought for badger, deer and bear gentle painter. But we will no longer quietly fall back from their axes and saws. We will stand and fight whatever way we can, whatever way we have to." She looked up at the sky at some clouds that now seemed to Shemun to have a slight greenish cast to them. "I just hope it will be enough."
As she turned and walked away Shemun felt the forest becoming a bit colder, a bit darker. He took a piece of charcoal and a sketchpad from his backpack and started sketching to capture what he saw.
- Shemun, Dural master painter talking to Eldarwen of the Ljosalfar

TEXT.English:
"Bah this is rotten!" Verlain said spitting out a morsel of whatever he had just put in his mouth seconds before. "Isss not rotten, isss presserved gorilla liver, keepss for yearss." the mazatl quartermaster that had been distributing the rations answered indignantly. "I can believe that this stuff won´t get any worse over the years cause not even a maggot would be caught dead eating it!. What did you do to it? Never heard of salting or drying?". The quartermaster looked at Verlain with contempt:"Drying iss no good in the sswampss. It will only get wet again alsso dry meat iss bad for your humourss. And ass for ssalting, ssalting iss even worsse. Ssalted food makess you ssluggish and ssluggish warriorss die. A warrior needss hiss blood quick and hiss mind nimble, and sso we prepare your rationss acordingly." Verlain looked sceptical:"To feed soldiers bad food to keep them in a bad mood i can understand, to feed them little to inspire them to loot also, but to feed them this..... It makes you want to murder the one who prepared it!" The small Mazatl looked indignant:"Only our besst hunterss are allowed to procure meat for our foreign mercenaries. Also great care is taking in the preparation. Firsst we drain the blood from the meat ass far ass is posssible. Then we put the meat in a jar and roast it slowly for several hourss, after that it is marinated in the presservative sauce. This sauce too iss mosst difficult to procure. It is the urine of panthers that hass been left out in the ssun to concentrate the quick essence of the beast and when itss conssisstency iss......" The quatermaster broke off his explanation and looked astonished at the mercenary who was trying to void his belly as best as he could. When Verlain finally could speak again he faced the quartermaster squarely and said:"From now on I will only eat imported salted meat and bread. I don´t care about maggots and I don´t care how hard the bread is but if you can´t feed me properly I will quit my contract tomorrow."
-Verlain, Grigori mercenary talking to Hcheziatl, Mazatl quartermaster

The quartermaster looked at Verlain with contempt:"Drying iss no good in the sswampss. It will only get wet again alsso dry meat iss bad for your humourss. And ass for ssalting, ssalting iss even worsse. Ssalted food makess you ssluggish and ssluggish warriorss die. A warrior needss hiss blood quick and hiss mind nimble, and sso we prepare your rationss acordingly." Verlain looked sceptical:"To feed soldiers bad food to keep them in a bad mood i can understand, to feed them little to inspire them to loot also, but to feed them this..... It makes you want to murder the one who prepared it!" The small Mazatl looked indignant:"Only our besst hunterss are allowed to procure meat for our foreign mercenaries. Also great care is taking in the preparation. Firsst we drain the blood from the meat ass far ass is posssible. Then we put the meat in a jar and roast it slowly for several hourss, after that it is marinated in the presservative sauce. This sauce too iss mosst difficult to procure. It is the urine of panthers that hass been left out in the ssun to concentrate the quick essence of the beast and when itss conssisstency iss......" The quatermaster broke off his explanation and looked astonished at the mercenary who was trying to void his belly as best as he could. When Verlain finally could speak again he faced the quartermaster squarely and said:"From now on I will only eat imported salted meat and bread. I don´t care about maggots and I don´t care how hard the bread is but if you can´t feed me properly I will quit my contract tomorrow."
-Verlain, Grigori mercenary talking to Hcheziatl, Mazatl quartermaster

TEXT.English:
Strife in itself is an integral part of life. We all struggle all of the time although our trials are very different. Some may struggle to keep food on the table, some to keep their families and friends safe and other might struggle against the unrelenting boredom that threatens to smother their lives. Struggle in itself is nothing to be avoided but to be unified and directed. For when a people as a whole focus their attentions on a single goal and use all their ingenuity, energy and skill to achieve it, it is a mighty struggle ideed. But thus harmony is born. Harmony does not exist by itself it needs discord strife and hardships to be able to manifest. Just as sound by itself is not music but pluck the right notes out of a sea of noise and you hear a chord to make angels weep.
- Einion Logos

TEXT.English:
Fools! Let them train their army. Let them assemble under the banner of the crusade. Let them come with their swords, axes and lances. And when they are almost ready to crush us, we will unleash our magic. Their crops will fail. Their lands will turn to sand and ashes. The fabric of reality will rend and whole towns will dissapear. It will be hell that reigns on erebus! And while their lands suffer our magic will reach out and simply snuff out the flickering candles these Bannor call life. So let them prepare I say. It will avail them nothing!
- Tebryn Arbandi

TEXT.English:
* The principle itself is simple *
Kalley was hiding in some bushes not farm from a farmstead listening to the mind voice of his instructor, watching the small family go about their business. The sun had just set and father and sun were repairing some fences in the fields while the mother and her two daughters were preparing supper from time to time a giggling infant could be heard whether boy or girl Kalley did not know but neither did he care.
* Clear your thoughts of distractions and place the wretch beside you *
Kalley had been told to fetch one of the many torture victims from the guilds dungeons. His teachers had insisted that he bring a broken man with him for this field test, now he would get to know why. He picked up the gagged wreck of a man and put him against the rough bark of a tree nearby. The bark opened some of the many wounds on the mans back but he did not resist. The wretch whimpering into his gag beside him disgusted Kalley but he soon found his center and became calm and ready to channel the flow of energies.
* In order to project despair convincingly true despair must be felt *
Kalley understood then. A mage despairing was a mage unable to focus and unable to cast so the feeling he wanted to project would by it´s very nature render him unable to use his powers. That was why they had told him to bring the wretch along.
* Now reach out to his thoughts and project his feelings at your target *
Kalleys brow furrowed in concentration as he put his left hand, the hand that absorbs, on the mans forehead. Then he slowly started to build a connection between the man and the cottage and as soon as he felt it was stable enough he began to channel emotion through it.
* Anchor the flow with the crystal we gave you *
Kalley took out a crystal the color of dried blood and concentrated on weaving the lines of power into it´s essence. That was never easy with entropy crystals but he had been practicing for two years now and it took him hardly more than an hour until he felt the slow draining of his power ease. The crystal now pulsated darkly and he knew that it would sustain the spell for at least a day.
* Observe the results of your spell *
Kalley looked at the small cottage but could see no movement so he slowly and silently went towards the window where some light could be seen. He could hear no sound but soft crying and sobbing from the small house. As he looked in throgh the window he saw the whole family sitting at their supper but no one was eating anymore. They were all sitting around the table motionless despair and desolation on their faces. The only sounds and movement came from the infant futilely trying to get a reaction from its mother. The light came from the hearth where a small fire still flickered it´s embers glowing red and Kalley thought, full of hunger.
* Move some of the embers into the bedding and observe *
Kalley used a small push of his telekinetic powers to move one of the embers into the bedding straw. And saw it catch fire almost immediately. He had always liked fire and seeing things burn so he stood at the window watching as the flames began to consume the small cottage. The family still did not move. They had turned to look at the fire and the father had begun to stand up, but resignation and despair had won out and he had sat down again. Only the baby wailed loudly as the flames came closer. Kalley began to walk away and his footsteps were accompanied by the screams of the burning family and the roar of the hungry flames.
* Now you understand. Tomorrow you will join the others. Adept. *
- The trials of Kalley, former Hippus arsonist

TEXT.English:
Lore:
The walls are high the soldiers brave, the knights are proud the arrows true, they charge our walls wave after wave, they say they´ve won, if they only knew.
In our dreams we leave this place, In our dreams we spread the fear, In our dreams we call the darkness, In our dreams our lords are near!
We cower here inside our fortress, no relief is on it´s way they say they´re light and we are darkness, to cleanse the taint they´ve come they say.
In our dreams we leave this place, In our dreams we spread the fear, In our dreams we call the darkness, In our dreams our lords are near!
At day they fight and we must fear them, but as night falls our turn is come, our thoughts take shape and walk amongst them, hear the music, hear them run!
In our dreams we leave this place, In our dreams we spread the fear, In our dreams we call the darkness, In our dreams our lords are near!
Dream brothers! Dream!
-Dylain Seaweaver, Cultist of the Overlords leading his brothers in prayer during the siege of Shaolfort

Dream brothers! Dream!
-Dylain Seaweaver, Cultist of the Overlords leading his brothers in prayer during the siege of Shaolfort

TEXT.English:
Verlain looked down at the great city of Kingsport and felt despair. Hundreds of sails could be seen in its harbor and dozens more out at sea. As if that was not enough he could spot 3 trading caravans trundling to the hills wagons heavily laden with exotic goods and each of those was at least fifty people and more than a hundred animals strong.
"We should have caught him in the hills, we will never find him here. And if he manages to leave the city it will take us weeks to pick up his trace again." The greyclad ranger beside him also looked at the city pensively then said without looking at Verlain "Should and would are words of smoke. We did not and he is here. He must not escape us or the shadow masters would be wroth with us." Verlain grimaced. "It´s just that I don´t care for dodging your masters´ asassins for the remainder of my days they don´t take kindly to failure Saraphan." The ranger let out a strange hissing sound and studied Verlain from the shadows of his hood. "No need to tell me of my masters Verlain, just see to it that no one disturbs my concentration as I ride." Then the flapping of dark wings could be heard, as a big raven landed on his shoulder and the ranger stiffened and closed his eyes. Then the raven took wing again and flew out towards the harbour.
Verlain had to concentrate to here Saraphans whispering voice. "Sails and more sails, sailors and cargo, shipmasters, timbers, barrels of water, dockside whores, shipmasters, captains and cabin boys, barrels full of rum and crates full of spices, beggars and cripples but no sign of our black pray." Verlain had lost sight of the raven out over the harbour but the ranger whispered on. "Five and twenty ships already left today" then followed a short pause and Verlain thought he could see a black shadow flying out to see following the ships that had already left. "Beautiful serpent bound for Tyll, cargo of spices and wool, Shining handmaiden, a galley bound for Elven lands with a cargo of wine and leathers,....." and so it went on a list of ships and destinations that seemed to be all over Erebus. Verlain saw sweat trickling down then rangers face. "Then the raven seemed to fly over land. "Four and sixty camels bound for Lodente, two and twenty mules bound for the underhome with twenty dwarves and one human." The rangers voice grew more intent. "Clad in darkness, his face hooded always hiding between mules, going towards a tunnel entrance, a crossbow!" Saraphan screamed in agony, clutched his chest and then seemed to shudder. Verlain stepped closer and shook him by the shoulder shouting "Come to man! Come to! I need to know what´s happening!" Saraphan opened his eyes and looked around obviosly disoriented, then he took a deep breath and started to run. "He killed Fogrider and he is about to enter the dwarven tunnels! Come we must make haste Verlain!"
As Verlain made to follow the ranger he muttered "Dwarves, why does it have to be bloody dwarves?"
-Verlain Grigori, mercenary hunting for the umbricide

TEXT.English:
Shemun was unhurriedly strolling through the streets of Hardshire, a Bannor trading city situated on the gulf of flame. To look at the city one would hardly have guessed this to be a center of the dye trade. The piers were rather small few ships were to be seen and hardly a merchant stall in sight. This was a city of banks and branch offices. Its inhabitants were well dressed men and women going about their business quietly. There were no warehouses and few wares on display. This was the nervecenter of the dye trade but few of the dyes bought and sold here ever saw the city.
Soon Shemun had reached his destination and knocked on the unremarkle door of a well to do but by no means ostentatious house he knew to be the residence and offices of Alkar Loomhand one of the foremost traders of the city. The door was opened only seconds later and he was ushered in by a middle age serving woman. "Please be kind enough to wait in the salon young master." She said gesturing towars the door on his right. "The master is talking to one of his other clients but he will soon have time for you. I will bring you some refreshments, please make yourself comfortable."
The salon was a comfortable room tastefully furnished, but Shemun allowed that he might be prejudiced since two of the paintings on the wall were of his own make. He did not have to wait long, his cup of tea was still too hot to drink when Master Alkar entered the room and smiled at him as soon as he saw him. Alkar was a painfully thin man with a balding head and a carefully trimmed grey beard. "Always a pleasure to see you my young friend", he said while shaking Shamuns hand. "You know how much I admire your genius so have you come to buy or sell my friend?" "I was hoping for a trade Alkar. I am afraid I would not be able to pay in coin for what I need." Alkar smiled. "Another one of your exotic paint ingredients eh? Well you are lucky then that I need a new painting for my daughters room. So what is it you need?" Shemun lowered his voice. "I need a very special kind of ink called Razorweed spirit. And as you doubtless know it is impossible to get the stuff via regular channels." The merchant shook his head thoughtfully. "I hope you know what you are doing my friend, what you want is not only hard to get but also highly illegal." Shemun nodded. "I know Alkar. But I simply can´t paint the piece I have been comissioned to paint without it. It just would not look right." The merchant grimaced: "You are in luck then since the 14th Crusader Auxiliaries and the chapter of eternal vigilance have advanced a bit further into unclaimed broken lands last month and I heard they lost some men to razorweed. And as luck would have it I know the commander of the 14th. But...... It will cost you more than just one painting. I am willing to offer my services for one painting of your choice and one I will comission you to do at a later date but the soldiers gathering that hellish stuff for you will want to see some golden coins for their trouble. I think 200 should suffice."
Two hours later Shemun started his journey home. The bargain had cost him dearly but at least he would now be able to finish ascent to Erebus at last.
-Biography of Shemun, Dural master painter

To look at the city one would hardly have guessed this to be a center of the dye trade. The piers were rather small few ships were to be seen and hardly a merchant stall in sight. This was a city of banks and branch offices. Its inhabitants were well dressed men and women going about their business quietly. There were no warehouses and few wares on display. This was the nervecenter of the dye trade but few of the dyes bought and sold here ever saw the city.
Soon Shemun had reached his destination and knocked on the unremarkle door of a well to do but by no means ostentatious house he knew to be the residence and offices of Alkar Loomhand one of the foremost traders of the city. The door was opened only seconds later and he was ushered in by a middle age serving woman. "Please be kind enough to wait in the salon young master." She said gesturing towars the door on his right. "The master is talking to one of his other clients but he will soon have time for you. I will bring you some refreshments, please make yourself comfortable."
The salon was a comfortable room tastefully furnished, but Shemun allowed that he might be prejudiced since two of the paintings on the wall were of his own make. He did not have to wait long, his cup of tea was still too hot to drink when Master Alkar entered the room and smiled at him as soon as he saw him. Alkar was a painfully thin man with a balding head and a carefully trimmed grey beard. "Always a pleasure to see you my young friend", he said while shaking Shamuns hand. "You know how much I admire your genius so have you come to buy or sell my friend?" "I was hoping for a trade Alkar. I am afraid I would not be able to pay in coin for what I need." Alkar smiled. "Another one of your exotic paint ingredients eh? Well you are lucky then that I need a new painting for my daughters room. So what is it you need?" Shemun lowered his voice. "I need a very special kind of ink called Razorweed spirit. And as you doubtless know it is impossible to get the stuff via regular channels." The merchant shook his head thoughtfully. "I hope you know what you are doing my friend, what you want is not only hard to get but also highly illegal." Shemun nodded. "I know Alkar. But I simply can´t paint the piece I have been comissioned to paint without it. It just would not look right." The merchant grimaced: "You are in luck then since the 14th Crusader Auxiliaries and the chapter of eternal vigilance have advanced a bit further into unclaimed broken lands last month and I heard they lost some men to razorweed. And as luck would have it I know the commander of the 14th. But...... It will cost you more than just one painting. I am willing to offer my services for one painting of your choice and one I will comission you to do at a later date but the soldiers gathering that hellish stuff for you will want to see some golden coins for their trouble. I think 200 should suffice."
Two hours later Shemun started his journey home. The bargain had cost him dearly but at least he would now be able to finish ascent to Erebus at last.
-Biography of Shemun, Dural master painter

TEXT.English: Farmers markets can be built in any city that has acess to a grain resource. They consume some food but provide money for every grain resource you control. Also they allow you to build a bakery each in your nobles districts.

TEXT.English:
"Look down there mylord and tell me what you see." The pruple clad official called Ashdor said pointing towards the window. Caladien looked outside at the bustling little market place and said dismissively: "It is just a farmers market. Where people buy and sell the foodstuffs they grow in the fields surrounding the city." "Yes my lord more to the point it is the farmers market where the people from Longvale sell their wheat. During harvesting season dozens of carts come in every day and their grain is sold on this market." "I don´t really grasp your meaning Ashdor. I know the tariffs we get from this market barely justify the expense of keeping tax collectors here and as far as I can see giving away longvale for lasting peace will cost neither the city nor the empire much in the long run." Ashdor sighed. "You are of course right my lord, the tariffs collected here are marginal. But the grain sold here is mostly sold to long distance traders. And we collect further tarrifs at the harbour and at the city gates. Also most of the grain that gets sold here ends up in the bakeries of our capital. So if we were to give away longvale we would suffer a minimal tax hit here a small one at the harbour and at the city gates, but most importantly we would be forced to import grain to keep the supply situation in our capital stable." "You are telling me there will be famine if we give away longvale?" Ashor looked down at the thriving market again: "No my lord not famine. But it would become harder to feed the capital and the army. And if we loose another fertile region in the future then there will be famine. So I urge you to think about this. If I were in your position I would rather give away the coppermines of yellow hills then the wheat fields of longvale."
- Discussions about the peace settlement of the Golgarn trade wars

Shemun was unhurriedly strolling through the streets of Hardshire, a Bannor trading city situated on the gulf of flame. To look at the city one would hardly have guessed this to be a center of the dye trade. The piers were rather small few ships were to be seen and hardly a merchant stall in sight. This was a city of banks and branch offices. Its inhabitants were well dressed men and women going about their business quietly. There were no warehouses and few wares on display. This was the nervecenter of the dye trade but few of the dyes bought and sold here ever saw the city.
Soon Shemun had reached his destination and knocked on the unremarkle door of a well to do but by no means ostentatious house he knew to be the residence and offices of Alkar Loomhand one of the foremost traders of the city. The door was opened only seconds later and he was ushered in by a middle age serving woman. "Please be kind enough to wait in the salon young master." She said gesturing towars the door on his right. "The master is talking to one of his other clients but he will soon have time for you. I will bring you some refreshments, please make yourself comfortable."
The salon was a comfortable room tastefully furnished, but Shemun allowed that he might be prejudiced since two of the paintings on the wall were of his own make. He did not have to wait long, his cup of tea was still too hot to drink when Master Alkar entered the room and smiled at him as soon as he saw him. Alkar was a painfully thin man with a balding head and a carefully trimmed grey beard. "Always a pleasure to see you my young friend", he said while shaking Shamuns hand. "You know how much I admire your genius so have you come to buy or sell my friend?" "I was hoping for a trade Alkar. I am afraid I would not be able to pay in coin for what I need." Alkar smiled. "Another one of your exotic paint ingredients eh? Well you are lucky then that I need a new painting for my daughters room. So what is it you need?" Shemun lowered his voice. "I need a very special kind of ink called Razorweed spirit. And as you doubtless know it is impossible to get the stuff via regular channels." The merchant shook his head thoughtfully. "I hope you know what you are doing my friend, what you want is not only hard to get but also highly illegal." Shemun nodded. "I know Alkar. But I simply can´t paint the piece I have been comissioned to paint without it. It just would not look right." The merchant grimaced: "You are in luck then since the 14th Crusader Auxiliaries and the chapter of eternal vigilance have advanced a bit further into unclaimed broken lands last month and I heard they lost some men to razorweed. And as luck would have it I know the commander of the 14th. But...... It will cost you more than just one painting. I am willing to offer my services for one painting of your choice and one I will comission you to do at a later date but the soldiers gathering that hellish stuff for you will want to see some golden coins for their trouble. I think 200 should suffice."
Two hours later Shemun started his journey home. The bargain had cost him dearly but at least he would now be able to finish ascent to Erebus at last.
-Biography of Shemun, Dural master painter
