TEXT.English:
Saraphans grey form was almost invisble against the mist behind him and amongst the brush and small trees on the hilltop. Still he had a clear view of the dwaven pioneers setting up the small settlement they called Rockhomme on a gentle rise beside the bank of the greenwater. The settlement was very young, a collection of huts with a few hundred dwarves as inhabitants at best and only a green unit of maybe one hundred dwarven slingers as defenders. It was no threat to anyone..... yet. But the elder shades of Celo had decreed that the dwarves had settled to close to Sidar lands and so sent Shaladar and his rangers to raze it. Shaladar had sent out Fogrider, his Raven companion, earlier and had seen nothing to change his assesment that this would not be a difficult task. True the dwarves had built on a hilltop to allow their slingers greater range and slow down attackers but the dense forests that grew around Rockhomme would hide his rangers until they were very close and the gentle slope of the hill would do little to slow his men. The dwarves had also started on building Palisades but those were crude at best and unfinished in many places. Satisfied that tomorrow should be an easy victory Shaladar descended from his Lookout to wait for the arrival of his fellow rangers.
He woke from his shallow dreamless sleep with a start and heard a loud grumbling in the distance. The sound seemed to be coming from the direction of Rockhomme. His men were up and armed as well but no threat materialized. Then other sounds could be heard as he climbed back to the hilltop, water gurgling, stones falling, wood breaking. He reached the summit but could see nothing of Rockhomme. Although it was a clear and cloudless night thick fog seemed to surround the dwarven settlement in all directions. He spent the rest of the night on the hilltop futilely trying to get a glance of what was going on.
As the new dawn came he could see the Fog for what it really was an enormous cloud of dust. But the dust that had risen in the night had already partially settled so he could see the outlines of Rockhomme again and what he saw dismayed him. Gone was the covered approach to the city the trees had fallen for two hundred yards out from the base of the hill and not fallen randomly but in patterns that would slow any approach. Gone also was the gentle rise easy to climb instead the dwarven settlement now stood on a steep cliff. The rock had fallen away to form a dam in the Greenwater on one side and on the other side provided now dams for the new riverbed that formed a moat around the hill. The only dry approach to the settlement was now from the other bank of the greenwater across the dam of fallen stone and out of his reach. The palisades were still unfinished but perched atop steep cliffs this was empty consolation. He shook his head in wonderment and descended to his waiting men.
"We go back. If the Elders still want Rockhomme gone they will have to send an army."
-Shaladar, Sidar Ranger
TEXT.French:
Saraphans grey form was almost invisble against the mist behind him and amongst the brush and small trees on the hilltop. Still he had a clear view of the dwaven pioneers setting up the small settlement they called Rockhomme on a gentle rise beside the bank of the greenwater. The settlement was very young, a collection of huts with a few hundred dwarves as inhabitants at best and only a green unit of maybe one hundred dwarven slingers as defenders. It was no threat to anyone..... yet. But the elder shades of Celo had decreed that the dwarves had settled to close to Sidar lands and so sent Shaladar and his rangers to raze it. Shaladar had sent out Fogrider, his Raven companion, earlier and had seen nothing to change his assesment that this would not be a difficult task. True the dwarves had built on a hilltop to allow their slingers greater range and slow down attackers but the dense forests that grew around Rockhomme would hide his rangers until they were very close and the gentle slope of the hill would do little to slow his men. The dwarves had also started on building Palisades but those were crude at best and unfinished in many places. Satisfied that tomorrow should be an easy victory Shaladar descended from his Lookout to wait for the arrival of his fellow rangers.
He woke from his shallow dreamless sleep with a start and heard a loud grumbling in the distance. The sound seemed to be coming from the direction of Rockhomme. His men were up and armed as well but no threat materialized. Then other sounds could be heard as he climbed back to the hilltop, water gurgling, stones falling, wood breaking. He reached the summit but could see nothing of Rockhomme. Although it was a clear and cloudless night thick fog seemed to surround the dwarven settlement in all directions. He spent the rest of the night on the hilltop futilely trying to get a glance of what was going on.
As the new dawn came he could see the Fog for what it really was an enormous cloud of dust. But the dust that had risen in the night had already partially settled so he could see the outlines of Rockhomme again and what he saw dismayed him. Gone was the covered approach to the city the trees had fallen for two hundred yards out from the base of the hill and not fallen randomly but in patterns that would slow any approach. Gone also was the gentle rise easy to climb instead the dwarven settlement now stood on a steep cliff. The rock had fallen away to form a dam in the Greenwater on one side and on the other side provided now dams for the new riverbed that formed a moat around the hill. The only dry approach to the settlement was now from the other bank of the greenwater across the dam of fallen stone and out of his reach. The palisades were still unfinished but perched atop steep cliffs this was empty consolation. He shook his head in wonderment and descended to his waiting men.
"We go back. If the Elders still want Rockhomme gone they will have to send an army."
-Shaladar, Sidar Ranger

TEXT.English:
I´d rather fight an Amurite mage than those Sheaim bastards any day. Sure being burnt to cinders is neither nice nor pleasant and there ain´t much you can do on a battlefield to protect yourself from random lightning strikes, but however they kill you at least it´s quick.
The Sheaim on the other hand...... They like to make you suffer. You ever broke a limb and had to wear a cast my friend? I had one on my leg once and there was always this itching spot right above my ankle that no matter how hard I tried, I just could not scratch. One of their favourite spells is like that only much much worse. I should know, I got hit by it once. The pain was excruciating but not incapacitating. It was not designed to make you lie down and moan in agony, it was designed to make you mad. And the only thing your pain-addled brain can come up with to make it stop is to kill the son of a bitch who laid that spell on you.
So you go charging out of your own positions and into the enemy. You don´t care how many of them there are nor how well entrenched they might be. You just want to strangle the bastard. And all the while, you charge across the field and your comrades are being hacked down around you, you hear his cruel mocking laughter in your head. Taunting you, daring you to get him. I only survived that day because my own captain hamstrung me. Most of my friends were not so lucky.
- Heard in a Grigori veterans hospital

TEXT.English:
"Dear councilors, we Ljosalfar stand alone against the tide of darkness. We fight to defend our homes and our freedoms. But.. it pains me to say we are loosing. So I ask you to stand with us now! Yes, I know we are not followers of Lugus or Junil, but we stand against the darkness now while your priests preach about its coming. Alone we will fall. I cannot say if it will be next year or in a decade but without some assistance, from somewhere or someone, we cannot stand against the forces of evil. We need your help esteemed councillors!
I urge you to set aside past grievances and fogive or forget past wrongs. For the past is gone, never to change, but the future is ours to forge! Together we can make the forests of my people into a fortress the darkness can never penetrate! Together we can drive back the demons and the undead that plague our lands. Together we can build an alliance that can vanquish this darkness forever and reestablish the compact our gods agreed upon!
No matter our differences in appearance or custom, when compared to our enemies we are all brothers and sisters to one another. So let us be as one people, as one nation, until we have driven back the night and ensured peace and safety for all our peoples. This is called the age of rebirth, so let the old peace that once reigned between us be reborn now, and to help build a safe and prosperous future for all of us. We come before you as petitioners but we do not come with empty hands. We offer our soldiers and fortresses, we offer our friendship and alliance. All you have to do is accept and step forward together into a bright and valiant future!"
- Elven war leader Ivelleth speaking before the Overcouncil

TEXT.English:
Akris stumbled through an overgrown riverbed. He was exhausted and shaking with fear. Also filled with shame as he had just lost his first command. The elders of the Chapter of the Burning Rose had entrusted him to lead Astrums levies against a lair of vile undead that haunted the hills north of the city. But Akris himself, just like many of his men had run when the Spectres came wailing towards them. Their cries had been a bonechilling shriek, while their bodies resembled humanoid shadows that flickered in and out of sight as they just passed through trees and boulders that lay before their path. Akris to his shame had broken and ran. He had not stopped running since then and now he had no idea where he was, nor what had happened to his command. The sun had come over the horizon hours ago, when he finally managed to clear his head enough of to stop. He had trouble breathing, his throat felt dry as sandpaper and as he fumbled for his canteen, he realized he had dropped it somewhere during his flight. He spent several hours looking for something, anything to drink, but found only some bitter berries that made his stomach cramp. At least though, it took care of the worst of his thirst, then he set out to find other survivors.
Night had already fallen when he finally heard human voices again. He had drunk from a pond during his wanderings and had even found some nutritious roots along his path. Now he heard voices which were the first sign of survivors he had come across, since he fled the hill. He stopped and listened. They were coming from beyond a hillcrest and the loudest among them was a prayer to Junil. At least a dozen people had joined their voices to a triumphant chorus, thanking Junil for the courage and resolve he had blessed them with, but also asking that he keep his chosen from harm this dark night. He sighed with relief that he did not have to spend the night alone in the forest and went towards the voices.
"Lord of Justice preserve us! Keep the unclean from us! We who keep thy order on Erebus, beseech thee for thy blessings!"
The chorus of voices chanted. And a single voice answered leading them in their prayer.
"We few who have walked through hell and returned, we vow to stand between the darkness and the light, to defend those who cannot fight themselves from all those foes who defy thine holy order!"
He could see fires beyond the hills crest and now also heard moans and the rattle of armor. He could smell food being prepared. But mixed with the appetizig smells were the smells of funeral pyres. Of men burnt to keep them from rising again this night.
"Lord of justice preserve us! No matter how horrid our foe, how unequal the odds we shall stand, to defend your will and your order!"
Akris had crested the hill and saw maybe fifty survivors on top of an old burial mound around a big blazing fire. A cleric of Junil was leading the prayer of those well enough to pray, while in the flickering shadows the big fire cast many lay wounded or despairing. There were sentries too, but these were not Bannor soldiers, but ghostly figures glowing softly in the darkness. Akris had heard of such spirits but never seen them, they were the ghosts of fallen heroes, no doubt buried at this ancient site and they obviously had agreed to defend the ragged band that had sought shelter here. He stumbled into the camp helped by two of the silent glowing sentinels, and after a night and a day of fear he finally felt safe again.
"We beseech you Lord do not judge us harshly, for we are but mortal men and mortal flesh. And though law and order are unyielding and unbending, we are weak without your help.
So keep from us death and darkness this night, for we have already been tried sorely. Keep from us the unliving and the undying for thy will is our law and thy mercy our salvation."

"You have been sorely tried my son but you are safe here. I beseeched Junil for protection and he sent these heroes of a past age to be our guards and sentinels tonight. Akris was almost ready to give up when they finally reached the fallen heroes guarding the camp and the shadows fled into the night.
He stood beside the cleric panting. Both of them too winded to speak, both tired and hurting. The cleric caught his breath first and panted: "Thank you my friend. Small white fires still burned wherever they had slain a shadow. It looked pretty and peaceful now. "The attack on us bodes ill." The cleric continued in a quiet voice. "The Einherjar warned me that our presence had awakened an ancient evil they had tried to seal away long ago. But I did not think it would grow in power that fast. The voice made Akris hairs stand on end and the familiar feeling of terror stole over him once again. The nimbus of light he had called again died with a flicker and he screamed in pain as he was drawn back into the darkness. And wailing could be heard from the darkness of the forest. It sounded hungry, angry and full of envy. But amidst the ghostly screams the very human voice of the cleric could be heard, the high pitched scream of someone in terrible unbearable pain. And Akris ran. He ran past the ghostly sentinels that had drawn together as if awaiting an attack and past the wounded moaning and trying to crawl away. He ran out into the darkness beyond the firelight and into the forest where the small fires still burned.
The fall of Astrum - A true tale by Cpt. Akris Steelheart

Their cries had been a bonechilling shriek, while their bodies resembled humanoid shadows that flickered in and out of sight as they just passed through trees and boulders that lay before their path. Akris to his shame had broken and ran. He had not stopped running since then and now he had no idea where he was, nor what had happened to his command. The sun had come over the horizon hours ago, when he finally managed to clear his head enough of to stop. He had trouble breathing, his throat felt dry as sandpaper and as he fumbled for his canteen, he realized he had dropped it somewhere during his flight. He spent several hours looking for something, anything to drink, but found only some bitter berries that made his stomach cramp. At least though, it took care of the worst of his thirst, then he set out to find other survivors.
Night had already fallen when he finally heard human voices again. He had drunk from a pond during his wanderings and had even found some nutritious roots along his path. Now he heard voices which were the first sign of survivors he had come across, since he fled the hill. He stopped and listened. They were coming from beyond a hillcrest and the loudest among them was a prayer to Junil. At least a dozen people had joined their voices to a triumphant chorus, thanking Junil for the courage and resolve he had blessed them with, but also asking that he keep his chosen from harm this dark night. He sighed with relief that he did not have to spend the night alone in the forest and went towards the voices.
"Lord of Justice preserve us! Keep the unclean from us! We who keep thy order on Erebus, beseech thee for thy blessings!"
The chorus of voices chanted. And a single voice answered leading them in their prayer.
"We few who have walked through hell and returned, we vow to stand between the darkness and the light, to defend those who cannot fight themselves from all those foes who defy thine holy order!"
He could see fires beyond the hills crest and now also heard moans and the rattle of armor. He could smell food being prepared. But mixed with the appetizig smells were the smells of funeral pyres. Of men burnt to keep them from rising again this night.
"Lord of justice preserve us! No matter how horrid our foe, how unequal the odds we shall stand, to defend your will and your order!"
Akris had crested the hill and saw maybe fifty survivors on top of an old burial mound around a big blazing fire. A cleric of Junil was leading the prayer of those well enough to pray, while in the flickering shadows the big fire cast many lay wounded or despairing. There were sentries too, but these were not Bannor soldiers, but ghostly figures glowing softly in the darkness. Akris had heard of such spirits but never seen them, they were the ghosts of fallen heroes, no doubt buried at this ancient site and they obviously had agreed to defend the ragged band that had sought shelter here. He stumbled into the camp helped by two of the silent glowing sentinels, and after a night and a day of fear he finally felt safe again.
"We beseech you Lord do not judge us harshly, for we are but mortal men and mortal flesh. And though law and order are unyielding and unbending, we are weak without your help.
So keep from us death and darkness this night, for we have already been tried sorely. Keep from us the unliving and the undying for thy will is our law and thy mercy our salvation."
Those were the last words Akris heard before he fell into a blissfully, unfeeling unconsciousness. He woke some time later, it was still night and found the cleric sitting beside him. He was an older man, his hair graying and his forehead and well trimmed beard gave his face a stern cast. But the wrinkles around his eyes suggested humor and compassion. "You have been sorely tried my son but you are safe here. I beseeched Junil for protection and he sent these heroes of a past age to be our guards and sentinels tonight. We have managed to put some food together and not far from here is a spring of clear cold water, so you will be able to regain some strength before we withdraw fully tomorrow." Akris looked around the camp and not much had changed since he had arrived, so he guessed that he had not been unconscious for long. "Follow me my son I will lead you to the spring and then we will see that you get something to eat."
They left the silent sentinels behind them and followed a path down the hillside. While they talked about the attack and how to best find the other bands of survivors, they suspected scattered in these dark forests. The forest was quiet and the gentle silver moonlight was bright enough to see by. They soon reached the spring the cleric had spoken of and as Akris bent down to drink, his companion washed his hands, bloodied by caring for the wounded a bit further downstream. He had barely drunk two handfulls of water when the cleric's voice rang through the silent forest and a deep chill ran down his spine. "Father of law stand by us!" He felt more than than saw dark shapes passing him by. "Give your warriors the courage to stand!" The fear in his hard was sunddenly replaced by ire. He would not run again! Akris turned and drew his axe in one fluid motion. Then he ran towards the cleric that was loudly praying a few yards downstream. Shadowy shapes darted around him but he was surrounded by a nimbus of bright white light and they seemed unable to come nearer. But even as Akris drew nearer he could see the light dimming. The cleric had lifted his hammer high above his head and called triumphantly. "Give our wepons of the essence of law so that we may help uphold the eternal order and smite those who break the laws of life and death!" And with that the clerics hammer burst into a holy white fire. As Akris charged to help him he saw his own weapon flaming with a paler version of the cleric's flame and was astonished to find the shades recoiled from his presence as well. His axe cleft a shadow in two, the severed pieces falling to the ground as burning pieces of cloth, and he turned to face the next shadow. The cleric smashed another apparition with the hammer while bashing yet another with his shield. But each hit seemed to dim the flames of his weapons a little. "We have to get back! We can´t fight them for long!" They started back up the hill, all the time fighting defending against a never ending stream of ghostly opponents. Akris was almost ready to give up when they finally reached the fallen heroes guarding the camp and the shadows fled into the night.
He stood beside the cleric panting. Both of them too winded to speak, both tired and hurting. The cleric caught his breath first and panted: "Thank you my friend. Had I made that descent alone to go wash, as I had intended, I would have died down there." Akris was still too breathless to speak so he just shook his head. "It is true my friend. Though Junils power is great it needs mortal vessels to manifest. Tonight you and I were his vessels." The cleric still panting looked down the track they had come. Small white fires still burned wherever they had slain a shadow. It looked pretty and peaceful now. "The attack on us bodes ill." The cleric continued in a quiet voice. "The Einherjar warned me that our presence had awakened an ancient evil they had tried to seal away long ago. But I did not think it would grow in power that fast. The hill fortress we tried to take yesterday is its old stronghold and our attack woke it they said. I never imagined that it would slip its bindings that fast."
"I was bound in blood and in blood I rise!" a toneless whisper came with the wind. "Blood is power and your army had much to spill." The voice made Akris hairs stand on end and the familiar feeling of terror stole over him once again. From the campfire panicked screams could be heard, while the cleric was looking around, searching for the origin of the voice. "I am dead yet deathless. Three times I was slain and two times I rose. The third time I discarded my useless flesh and now I wear the flesh of hundreds. And yours will make a fine addition." The voice was quiet as a whisper but could be heard everywhere on the hilltop. "You should have kept on running." A thick tendril of darkness whipped out of the darkness and wound around the clerics waist. The nimbus of light he had called again died with a flicker and he screamed in pain as he was drawn back into the darkness. And wailing could be heard from the darkness of the forest. It sounded hungry, angry and full of envy. But amidst the ghostly screams the very human voice of the cleric could be heard, the high pitched scream of someone in terrible unbearable pain. And Akris ran. He ran past the ghostly sentinels that had drawn together as if awaiting an attack and past the wounded moaning and trying to crawl away. He ran out into the darkness beyond the firelight and into the forest where the small fires still burned.
The fall of Astrum - A true tale by Cpt. Akris Steelheart

TEXT.English:
Undead are fearless. Why? Because they are mindless, only driven by the will of their creator. Undead feel no fear and will never refuse a command. They have no sense of self preservation. As you all know it is difficult tu hurl energies around even more so to hurl them at targets over great distances. So of course you can stop an attacking horde of skeletons by hurling fireball after fireball or calling lighning amongst their ranks. But no matter how many of them you destroy those you did not get will come on.
Fighting them with classical evocation you are pitting your strength against their strength. I grant you it is better than drawing your dagger and hurling yourself at them, but at the same time it is not a winning strategy. The best way to fight any enemy is to put your strength against their weakness. And their weakness is their singlemindedness. Literally in this case since a single necromancer of average power can hold hundreds of undead in thrall.
So the best way to fight them is either to go after their creator or failing that just to sever their connection to him. To this end we can use a simple anti magic enchantment we anchor to a line on the ground to sever the death mana flow between the necromancer and his creations. The enchantment itself is very simple and any adept can cast it. The trick is to get the undead to walk across the line, but usually the adept will suffice as bait. So if you plan to use this spell make damn sure you get it right. Because they WILL be coming for you, and if you messed it up they will get you.
- lecture: fighting the unholy without faith, by Leoris Coldwell, Amurite wizard

TEXT.English:
The bakery was like the interior of a chimney in midwinter now, Verlain thought. The flour had exploded forth from the sack he had hit his emloyer with, the hit had sent the fat man sprawling. But his lunge had only met with empty air. His eyes were useless now the flour made it impossible to see more than a few paces into the gloom that was poorly lit with the shielded lanterns the shop had mounted on the walls. But, Verlain comforted himself, so were the assasins blinded now and against invisible assasins sight was a poor tool anyways. So he focused on his hearing and on touch. Had he heard a floorboard creak to the right? His lunge met only air again. Had he felt the faint whisper of a breeze on his arm? He swung but there was nothing there.
Leoris the wizard was still ruther stunned from the speed with which events had unfurled but Verlain could hear him begin an incantation. It would give his position away but there was nothing for it. "No fire or we are all dead!" Then he threw himself to the right but the dagger still cut a deep furrow in his arm. Then there was silence again. Verlain crouched close to his employer who had begun to stir again. Thankfully his benefactor was to terrified to do anything that would tell the attacker where they were. The time for explanations would be later, if there was a later for them. Then Verlain heard glass break and someone running for the door. He hurled his dagger blindly and shouted: "We have to get out! This whole place is gonna go up in flames!" And he bent down to help his employer up.
The bakery and several other houses on the block were burning brightly. The citizens had formed bucket-chains and were dousing the surrounding houses in water trying to contain the spread of the fire. The bakery itself had been given up. Verlain and Leoris knelt beside their employer. They had made it out just in time but all three of them had suffered nasty burns. Leoris seemed the least injured. He had mumbled something about a fireshield cantrip being useful for once. They had laid their employer on the ground, opposite the bakery and had started on treating his wounds who was by far, the worst hurt. So Leoris had sent Verlain to fetch a healer. "What if the assasin returns?" Verlain had asked. "It is a very difficult mental exercise to bend light and shadow and allow oneself to become invisible, it takes hours and hours of preparation and meditation to achieve it. I am pretty sure that we were facing was a Sidar Ghost and even they cannot do it twice a week. So to become invisible twice a day is simply impossible." Verlain reluctantly went in search of a healer.
It had taken him no more than fifteen minutes, but when he returned, he saw Leoris talking to one of the city guards and an acolyte of Lugus already bent over his employer. He was still fifty yards away but he drew his sword and began running as fast as his injured legs allowed. The acolyte seemed to see him comming and unhurriedly stood said something to Leoris, who barely aknowledged him and entered a side street. Verlain was still 30 yards away and his shout of protest was lost in the roaring and crackling of the fires. Then he arrived at his employers side crimson gushing from the fat mans cut throat and the sidestreet the acolyte had entered was deserted. He stood there sword in hand in the light of the burning bakery and cursed himself for a fool. He had forgotten the first rule his master had taught him so long ago: "Never assume the enemy has only one way to end your life boy!"
-Verlain, a mercenaries life (autobiography) {chapter two - see chapter one at the bakery - editor}

But, Verlain comforted himself, so were the assasins blinded now and against invisible assasins sight was a poor tool anyways. So he focused on his hearing and on touch. Had he heard a floorboard creak to the right? His lunge met only air again. Had he felt the faint whisper of a breeze on his arm? He swung but there was nothing there.
Leoris the wizard was still ruther stunned from the speed with which events had unfurled but Verlain could hear him begin an incantation. It would give his position away but there was nothing for it. "No fire or we are all dead!" Then he threw himself to the right but the dagger still cut a deep furrow in his arm. Then there was silence again. Verlain crouched close to his employer who had begun to stir again. Thankfully his benefactor was to terrified to do anything that would tell the attacker where they were. The time for explanations would be later, if there was a later for them. Then Verlain heard glass break and someone running for the door. He hurled his dagger blindly and shouted: "We have to get out! This whole place is gonna go up in flames!" And he bent down to help his employer up.
The bakery and several other houses on the block were burning brightly. The citizens had formed bucket-chains and were dousing the surrounding houses in water trying to contain the spread of the fire. The bakery itself had been given up. Verlain and Leoris knelt beside their employer. They had made it out just in time but all three of them had suffered nasty burns. Leoris seemed the least injured. He had mumbled something about a fireshield cantrip being useful for once. They had laid their employer on the ground, opposite the bakery and had started on treating his wounds who was by far, the worst hurt. So Leoris had sent Verlain to fetch a healer. "What if the assasin returns?" Verlain had asked. "It is a very difficult mental exercise to bend light and shadow and allow oneself to become invisible, it takes hours and hours of preparation and meditation to achieve it. I am pretty sure that we were facing was a Sidar Ghost and even they cannot do it twice a week. So to become invisible twice a day is simply impossible." Verlain reluctantly went in search of a healer.
It had taken him no more than fifteen minutes, but when he returned, he saw Leoris talking to one of the city guards and an acolyte of Lugus already bent over his employer. He was still fifty yards away but he drew his sword and began running as fast as his injured legs allowed. The acolyte seemed to see him comming and unhurriedly stood said something to Leoris, who barely aknowledged him and entered a side street. Verlain was still 30 yards away and his shout of protest was lost in the roaring and crackling of the fires. Then he arrived at his employers side crimson gushing from the fat mans cut throat and the sidestreet the acolyte had entered was deserted. He stood there sword in hand in the light of the burning bakery and cursed himself for a fool. He had forgotten the first rule his master had taught him so long ago: "Never assume the enemy has only one way to end your life boy!"
-Verlain, a mercenaries life (autobiography) {chapter two - see chapter one at the bakery - editor}

TEXT.English:
"Any and all necromancers are very careful when raising the recently deceased. Human souls vary in strength and the strongest sometimes linger for a while clinging to their convictions, to their need to live. Animating such a corpse is often fatal to the necromancer since such an usurpation of a still inhabited body is extremely painful to the soul and thus it instinctively fights back. If it wins the initial struggle, it can use the energy the reanimation provides it with to fuel its movement, and quite often to kill a stunned or exhausted necromancer. But Necromancy is not the only way to give these strong souls power.
Sometimes their conviction of what is right, their dedication to ideals of a flag, or a nation, or their love of their friends and families keeps them from drifting away for a long time. So they linger behind, watching over what they held most dear or believed most important in life. Yet they are only able to affect our world in minuscule ways, even long after their bodies have rotted away. But, if we give them of our power, if we can provide them with enough energy to manifest, they will come back to us. Not as the vile specters the necromancers summon, for they have lost all nobility all purpose and thus are only tools for whatever dark power calls them. But as beings as noble, pure and dedicated as they had been in life. Of course we cannot control them, but what need is there? They cling to our world out of a deep felt need to help. All we need to do is to provide them with is the means, then we can march proudly beside our ancestors and heroes of the past."
-Sareen, Keeper of the Archives

TEXT.English:
We Doviello pride ourselves on strength, agility and stamina. But the strong and quick rarely develop the introspection and empathy needed to understand and interact with the spirit world. So when the hunting parties form in the spring, we shamans and wise women are often left behind, so that we do not slow down the hunters. So we perform our augurs, paint the warriors with hunting paint and then retreat to our caves and tents to await their return, but that does not mean we remain idle. We too are Doviello, the wolves of the north, the merciless stalkers, the many fanged pack. So while our hunters stalk the mammoth herds and snow bears, those of us who can, call their spirit guides and join the hunt as animals. We are the hawks that spy the herds, the wolves that follow the trails and even the great snow tigers that drive the herds towards waiting spears. Those of us who are old enough, and sufficiently attuned to the beyond are even able to spend our dreams experiencing the glory of the hunt, and the satisfaction of tasting the blood of a fresh kill. While you are limited to one skin I have worn many. And while you will be left behind by the pack when your body fails you. I will be hunting as long as there are predators to hear my call.
- Korosh, Doviello High Shaman

TEXT.English:
"Lift the rock young friend and then let it go. Observe that it returns to its mother as fast as it can. The same way she calls to this rock, she calls to all of her children, and so it comes that you and I are standing solidly on the ground. To climb away from her is often a very strenuous experience. We are like all children, we can never truly leave our parents behind. While we might part from her for some time, we will always come back to her. And although we are tiny and our voices are weak, if enough of us gather and call out to her, she will respond with motherly love and reach out towards us. You ask how we can create hills? We cannot. We can only call and if she wills it, she will answer."
-Karros, Khazad Druid

TEXT.English:
Pedia Strategy: The Bounty of Kilmorph spell enables your Runekeepers to discover a new minaral resource on a random plot within your empires borders.
Background:
The Khazad were at war. There was no shortage of young dwarves willing to fight. The years since the exodus from Underhome had seen a great increase in the dwarven population and the cities of the Khazad were filled with people, their vaults overflowing with gold, silver and gems. The craftsmen were still the most skilled in all of Erebus and the warriors well trained and dedicated. But all that had served to do was to provoke the greed of the Hippus. The merciless horselords had heard of Khazad wealth and they had come to take it not in trade but by force of arms. Now they were standing at Rockfall Pass and the fighting had been going on for months but eventually they would break through because there were no reinforcements to send. Oh there were enough dwarves willing to fight, but there was not enough steel to equip them. Not enough copper or even the beautiful silver and valuable gold were available for the Khazad, who could make servicable arms and armor even from such materials as these.
Runewarden Khalesh sat on the bare stonefloor of Rockfall Keep his head bowed in prayer, his hands caressing a fine chalice a silversmith had given him this morning as an offering to the earth mother to help the fortress in this time of peril. It was a masterpiece but the scenes it showed were grim indeed. Cavalry charging dwarven foragers, horses trampling priests, dwarven children running for their lives from a pack of Hippus hunting dogs. He felt the chalice and at the same time he felt the suffering of the dwarven people in the Keep and he felt the defenders fighting. They were brave and they were stubborn but they were also dying. Their blood flowing from the battlements they stood upon in small rivulets to sicker back into the earth from whence they had all come. Flowing back down to reuinte them with their mother. Khalesh followed the stream in his mind he followed it deep down into the rock where he felt the mothers presence and he felt her weeping. Weeping in anguish for the suffering of her children but also weeping in rage for the cruelty of the Hippus. Khalesh saw the blood and he saw the tears and where both liquids intersected he saw them harden to a silvery metal of utmost beauty. Born of suffering and sorrow this was a mothers gift to her children, a way to fight back against the invaders. Khalesh himself wept beholding it then he carefully retraced his steps in his mind and made certain he knew where the metal was to be found. Back in his body he immediatly ran to the Lord of Rockfall Keep. "Send for the head of the miners guild my lord. We have digging to do and there is not much time!"
-Chapter VII, the book of plenty

The merciless horselords had heard of Khazad wealth and they had come to take it not in trade but by force of arms. Now they were standing at Rockfall Pass and the fighting had been going on for months but eventually they would break through because there were no reinforcements to send. Oh there were enough dwarves willing to fight, but there was not enough steel to equip them. Not enough copper or even the beautiful silver and valuable gold were available for the Khazad, who could make servicable arms and armor even from such materials as these.
Runewarden Khalesh sat on the bare stonefloor of Rockfall Keep his head bowed in prayer, his hands caressing a fine chalice a silversmith had given him this morning as an offering to the earth mother to help the fortress in this time of peril. It was a masterpiece but the scenes it showed were grim indeed. Cavalry charging dwarven foragers, horses trampling priests, dwarven children running for their lives from a pack of Hippus hunting dogs. He felt the chalice and at the same time he felt the suffering of the dwarven people in the Keep and he felt the defenders fighting. They were brave and they were stubborn but they were also dying. Their blood flowing from the battlements they stood upon in small rivulets to sicker back into the earth from whence they had all come. Flowing back down to reuinte them with their mother. Khalesh followed the stream in his mind he followed it deep down into the rock where he felt the mothers presence and he felt her weeping. Weeping in anguish for the suffering of her children but also weeping in rage for the cruelty of the Hippus. Khalesh saw the blood and he saw the tears and where both liquids intersected he saw them harden to a silvery metal of utmost beauty. Born of suffering and sorrow this was a mothers gift to her children, a way to fight back against the invaders. Khalesh himself wept beholding it then he carefully retraced his steps in his mind and made certain he knew where the metal was to be found. Back in his body he immediatly ran to the Lord of Rockfall Keep. "Send for the head of the miners guild my lord. We have digging to do and there is not much time!"
-Chapter VII, the book of plenty

TEXT.English:
I prepare my mind, don my armor and wield my sword and shield.
I hear the signal and an arrow is fired my way. I quickly utter a protective incantation and the arrow suddenly jolts to my right, missing me entirely.
I hear the signal again and two arrows are fired my way. Thinking fast, I set ablaze the first arrow with an ignition cantrip, and deflect the second arrow with my shield.
It is the same training each day, but I bare no mind to the repetition.
-------------------------------------------------
"The days of a Swordmage in training are days of near constant mental taxation and physical exhaustion. For hours we are pushed to our limits. Preparing our spells, equipment, bodies and minds for the dangers that we will likely face once we leave the comforts of our barracks.
In Govannon, I see the perfect equilibrium of physical strength and iron willpower. It is through his teachings that I am able to find my own equilibrium. With my mind and body as one, I shall protect my kingdom and defeat any who dares to bare hostility against Kylorin's sacred children!" -Victor Talamello, aspiring Swordmage recruit.

TEXT.English:
"So you want to hear a tale of glories long gone? Ok then listen up I will tell you the story of the trials of Tesch´ Uggi a great Dwarven king. A long time ago no one is sure how long Tesch´Uggi was much beloved by his people but he was also lazy and so when he came out of underhome he decided he would build only one city and this one city he decided would be strong enough to dominate all of Erebus. So he sent runners to all the four corners of the world to find the perfect place for this marvel and after many adventures and many trials Tesch´Uggi had finally found the perfect spot for his city. In the bend of a great river close to where it joined the sea he would buid Occity the capital of Erebus or so he hoped. There was plenty of forest around his chosen spot with many a wild creature there to hunt, fertile plains close by where he could plant all kinds of grains and grazing lands for herds so big you have never seen their like not even the great cattledrives of the Hippus come close. The hills nearby seemed to be rich in precious stones and metals and the sea churned with fish. So he founded his city and it grew into a prosperous settlement but after a few years Tesch´Uggis subjects took up more and more of his time with their petty disputes and grievances. So he decided to install deputies that would judge such disputes in his stead. As the citiy grew the deputies became more and more and soon an entire district of Occity was given to them and they started to call themselves nobles and thought they were better than the dwarves who worked the fields, herded the cattle or toiled in the darkness of the mines. So now they began to argue amongst themselves and with those they had been chosen to lead. They wanted Jewelry but Tesch´Uggi could give them none because no one bothered with cutting the gems the miners found in Occity. You have to understand those were strict times then and one could either be a dwarf who had to work in the mines or the fields or the pastures the nobles owned or one was a noble oneself and to good for honest work. They wanted beer but Tesch`Uggi could give them none because the nobles did not want the stink of a brewery to pervade their gleaming district. They wanted many things and some of them the great king Tesch´Uggi could give to them others they themselves made impossible. Then came a time when the nobles of Occity saw another city grow not too far away and they urged Tesch´Uggi to declare war upon them. Long did Tesch´Uggi wait because he was lazy and he did not want to rule another city but finally he gave in and told his soldiers to burn the city to the ground and lead it´s people away to work in the mines and fields as slaves. But the city was across the sea and so to reach it they had to build big ships to carry their soldiers and those soldiers were heavy. A dwarf despite being smaller than a man is also much more compact thus weighing the same and the mines of Occity had produced weapons made of the finest steel and the furs of the animals they had hunted had been made into soft but durable armor so that each soldier had to carry around almost his own weight in equipment. And the generals came to Tesch´Uggi and said. Oh great king! Your army stands ready to attack those who build another city to rival your glorious creation but there is not enough wood to build our ships. And it was true because most of the forest that had surrounded the city had been cut away to make space for farms and the wood had gone underground to strenghten the mining tunnels. But Tesch´Uggi was wise and so he said: As there are animals that have better furs and Ores that hold more Iron there must be trees that are better in producing wood. And so he sent the finest minds of Occity into the woods to look for a Shipwoodtree. They searched from dawn till Dusk but found no such tree. After three months of searching there still was no wood for the ships so Tesch´Uggi stirred from his throne to look for himself. As he arrived in the forest he said to his people. I cannot believe that the gods have not made a tree that is fit for our needs, because the gods love Occity and they would not leave us alone in our plight. So Tesch`Uggi himself went looking for the Shipwoodtree and finally at dusk he came to a tree that looked special. It seemed to shimmer like bronze. He told his workers to cut all the trees of this kind, he called it Duskwood, and build the ships from them. But alas Tesch´Uggi knew many things but he did not know much about wood and the wood he had selected was the same as all the other trees that had been left because they were to weak to properly strenghten a mineshaft. And so his soldiers boarded the ships a few months later and they all sank into the ocean dragged down by their wonderous equipment. The other city was enraged at Tesch´Uggis plan and so they built a fleet of their own and burnt Occity to the ground. But from time to time one can still find things that have been fashioned in the great city of wonders and marvel at the craftsmanship that survives until today."
- heard in an inn in Balderham

And so his soldiers boarded the ships a few months later and they all sank into the ocean dragged down by their wonderous equipment. The other city was enraged at Tesch´Uggis plan and so they built a fleet of their own and burnt Occity to the ground. But from time to time one can still find things that have been fashioned in the great city of wonders and marvel at the craftsmanship that survives until today."
- heard in an inn in Balderham

TEXT.English:
............... and so we often find ourselves in remote locations without the benefit of well established corpse supply chains. So the first order of business for a necromancer looking to establish the backbone (no pun intended) of a self contained economy is to procure an adequate workforce. Fortunately for us few areas of Erebus are so hostile nowadays that no remains of living creatures can be found conveniently lying aroung. Many necromancers today feel that reanimating animal corpses is beneath their dignity, and while I agree with them in principle (far more difficult and less rewarding when equally available) unless you plan to get down on your knees and do your digging yourself I suggest that you swallow your pride for the moment. Assuming you are like most of colleagues you won´t have much luck trying to track animals on your own so your best bet is probably to look for a waterhole or caves where animals and/or their remains are usually plentiful. During your search keep your eyes peeled for signs of past human habitation we will need that knowledge later on (no matter how old or faint those signs may be). As soon as you have procured some animal remains, whether by killing live ones or by finding suitably well preserved ones, start reanimating your most promising diggers. Any and all quadrupeds should be able to dig in one fashion or another, but I personally prefer bears, wolves or badgers while I try to avoid hooved animals, but again choice is a luxury you will not always have.
Now that you have your impromtu workforce start looking for signs of human habitation. (For help in recognizing ancient burial sites see appendix B and use the appropriate subsection corresponding to your geographical and ethnological location.) Your common sense should tell you to stay clear of any presently thriving communities, pitchforks and torches have lost none of their power over the ages. But usually human nature has provided for an ample supply of untended graves in even the most remote locations. Old city ruins, battlefields or plague graves will work best but I also have used the grave of a long dead high chief once. When establishing your preliminary dig site two things are of the utmost importance. Number one is ease of acess you and your soon to be undead should be able to leave the dig at will without undue exertion. Number two is ease of concealment. If you start reanimating a mass grave in plain sight of a cities guard towers you will not be able to continue your budding career for much longer. Usually some sort of compromise is in order and I urge you to favour caution over ease of acess. Many is the young and promising necromancer.........
Copyists notes: This may be considered as the classical approach but necromancy has come a long way since then. If you cannot find a proper grave just ask a nearby city to send over a couple of hundred prisoners and ease of concealment is also rarely an issue.
- Necromancers field guide, Deathknell Edition

TEXT.English:
"The cave is damp." Kandra said. "Yes lassie. You see we use water to temper the metal all that heat evaporates the water and since we are deep underground and the walls are cool, the water decides to stay here instead of looking for a way out." The grizzled smith chuckled. "What else do you notice?" Kandra hesitated then forged on, "I expected noise and heat, but it is quiet here and the air is cool. Also I expected boisterous apprentices and haggling customers but we seem to be the only ones here." Grinning the old dwarf stroked his beard. "It can get quite loud down here when the army needs things done quick, quick. Always in a rush they are topside. But here in the underhome, little darling, we like to take our time with things nothing good comes of rushing things. Also we are alone here cause the loud mouthed boys you expected are home with their families, I wanted you to have the forge to yourself for your smithing." The dwarf went over to a low table where he lit a pipe and sat down puffing smoke contently. "The real reason we are in no rush, lass, is that we plan ahead. Y´see a human smith spends a few hours making a plow and it´ll serve the farmer well for a decade, perhaps two. But then the shoddy workmanship those humans call smithing will show its flaws and fall apart, and he will have to make another plow for the same farmer. And while the human smith might smile because of the added business brought on by his own incompetence, the farmer undoubtetly curses him under his breath. That is why human smiths are always in a hurry, they have to do all their work again and again. While we do things properly but only once if we can help it. That is not to say our wares don´t break but they break because of misuse or old age not because of faulty craftsmanship. And while humans are quite willing to pay good coin for a plow they won´t have to replace for generations, what they are really after is our weapons and I can´t blame them. I wouldn´t wanna go into battle with a sword I can expect to fail when I need it most. Ah well look at me talking and talking. I should be helping you finding your way around the forge shouldn´t I? Well then soon begun-soon mended as my old master used to say. What do you need for your little project?"
-from "Search for Perfection", by Kandra Silverglitter

TEXT.English:
Kandra stood before the showcases of the jewel smith, a gleam of longing in her dark brown eyes. The Master Smith was just finishing a sale to some noble of house thorne. The noble had evidently come to have a new signet ring made since his family had found a new vein of gold ore and thus the crest of his house had changed. Their rumbling voices argued quietly over some artistic details of the new ring, while Kandra imagined herself clad in gowns of silk and furs wearing the sappihre necklace that she imagined would go creat with her copper hair. Her imagination had carried her far away to the sacred halls beneath the mountains where she would dance the statley dance of artisans with some handsome and sucessful smith at her side, when the voice of the jewel smith abruptly brought her back to his shop.
"Can I help you dama?" Kandra looked up at him, he stood tall for a dwarf, and said rather hesitantly: "This might be a rather odd request and believe me, I do not wish to offend but I have a question to ask." "Iron and stone won´t be broken by words dama. Ask what you will." The smith quoted the old proverb and looked at her expectantly. "I have been told to find the most perfect of all the crafts. And so I came here hoping you could tell me where perfection can be found in the smiths art." "Aaah, so you are studying to become a thane dama? Very well I will answer as best I can but I warn you most answers you will hear will be different." The smith chuckled softly when he saw the look of surprise at her face.
"I can see that I am the first you visit with this question and I am honored dama. My answer is perfection can be found in many ways, sometimes it comes when you create something simple yet elegant, like a simple chain of copper links that falls gracefully. Sometimes you find it in the complexities of etching a family crest for a family so old and honorable it seems there is no way you can fit it all on a ring. But when you finish it looks just..... right. But most often I find perfection in perfecting my customers. If you find exactly the right trinket, the right ring the right diadem, you can make the other more of him or herself. A ring that might look perfect on one woman might make the other look too frail. A sapphire necklace perfect for the bride of a warrior would look out of place on a student of Kilmorph and so make her feel out of place."
Kandra tore her eyes from the necklace in the showcase and blushed a little. "I am sorry master smith i did not mean to appear inattentive." "Wait here dama I have something to give you." The smith went to his counter and opened a small ebony box. Then brought back a necklace of copper with a small silver and gold hammer, the symbol of Kilmorph, affixed to it and fastened it carefully around Kandras strong neck. "I made this for Orla my daughter but the blight took her. I kept working on it for years after that trying to make it perfect so that I might have something to remember her by. But perfection eluded me because without my daughter it could never be more than bits and pieces of metal. It fits you perfectly dama. I want you to have it." The eyes of the smith were bright with unshed tears as he looked at her. Kandra looked at the necklace around her neck and felt the cool metal on her skin. Then she looked at the smith and smiled with gratitude and empathy. "I am sure it would have fit your daughter perfectly. I thank you for this divine gift. And I will remember what you taught me today."
-from "Search for Perfection", by Kandra Silverglitter

And so I came here hoping you could tell me where perfection can be found in the smiths art." "Aaah, so you are studying to become a thane dama? Very well I will answer as best I can but I warn you most answers you will hear will be different." The smith chuckled softly when he saw the look of surprise at her face.
"I can see that I am the first you visit with this question and I am honored dama. My answer is perfection can be found in many ways, sometimes it comes when you create something simple yet elegant, like a simple chain of copper links that falls gracefully. Sometimes you find it in the complexities of etching a family crest for a family so old and honorable it seems there is no way you can fit it all on a ring. But when you finish it looks just..... right. But most often I find perfection in perfecting my customers. If you find exactly the right trinket, the right ring the right diadem, you can make the other more of him or herself. A ring that might look perfect on one woman might make the other look too frail. A sapphire necklace perfect for the bride of a warrior would look out of place on a student of Kilmorph and so make her feel out of place."
Kandra tore her eyes from the necklace in the showcase and blushed a little. "I am sorry master smith i did not mean to appear inattentive." "Wait here dama I have something to give you." The smith went to his counter and opened a small ebony box. Then brought back a necklace of copper with a small silver and gold hammer, the symbol of Kilmorph, affixed to it and fastened it carefully around Kandras strong neck. "I made this for Orla my daughter but the blight took her. I kept working on it for years after that trying to make it perfect so that I might have something to remember her by. But perfection eluded me because without my daughter it could never be more than bits and pieces of metal. It fits you perfectly dama. I want you to have it." The eyes of the smith were bright with unshed tears as he looked at her. Kandra looked at the necklace around her neck and felt the cool metal on her skin. Then she looked at the smith and smiled with gratitude and empathy. "I am sure it would have fit your daughter perfectly. I thank you for this divine gift. And I will remember what you taught me today."
-from "Search for Perfection", by Kandra Silverglitter

TEXT.English:
The sun was warm on his back and Varatus enjoyed the feeling while he worked. He had taken to working without his shirt on since his back had begun to trouble him a few weeks ago. As long as the sun was out and the wind was not too brisk, the warmth was soothing the aches and cramps he had accumulated over months of too much work and too little sleep. Even the painful twinge under his right shoulderblade seemed to lessen with the suns gentle kiss. But despite all the hardships the small aches and pains he was proud that he had been chosen to fashion the new statue of Junil for the new grand temple of in Torrolerial. It was to be his masterpiece. His friends had started joking about his devotion to this project, saying that he spent more time with his statue than many a newlywed man with his bride. But they had also tried to wheedle and cajoule him into showing them parts of his plans or a peak at the statue. And while it was true that he had spent almost every waking hour with his project what his friends did not know is that the statue even haunted his dreams. And so while he forbade them to look underneath the enormous sheets of canvas that covered the unfinished monument, except for whatever part he was currently working on he had gladly shown them the plans and joked with them, all the time trying to forget the disturbing images he saw night after night.
He could not remember his dreams in full, only single images stuck in his mind and a general feeling of dread and unease. A gloved hand covered in serrated spikes, a forlorn wailing voice like that of a lost child, the feeling of being chained and dragged underwater by the weight of those chains, voices in an emty room, menacing and demanding at the same time and always at the end the beautiful statue of Junil driving back the darkness. The last one was the only image that remained clear in his memory and so he had taken to pondering the benevolent yet sad mien the god seemed to wear whenever he appeared in his dreams. He had also lost time the lack of proper undisturbed sleep made him fidgety and several times his chisel had shattered stone that he wanted to carve so he had fallen behind. But people all over town were complaining of strange nightmares of late and so he decided not to dwell on it and started to work until late at night so he would fall into bed exhausted to tired to dream.
Varatus kept this up until the day of the unveiling came and while he was still disturbed by the images at night they had just fuelled his determination to finish the statue on time for the grand ceremony. And so he stood in the plaza of truth with the heads of the local orders beside him as Confessor Alvinius finished his speach. "............ and so brave soldiers brave citizens we are proud of your support in battling the Lanun child stealers and slave traders, last year we decided that we had had enough of their raiding, enough of their provocations and this year we celebrate the capture of Innishboffin the major center of slave trading this side of the eutrabean ranges. To mark this historic conquest the chapter of the inner flame commisioned a statue of our just lord Junil from your local master-sculptor Varatus. And it is my proud duty and honour to unveil it now, for all to be seen."
The canvas fell away and the speech was followed by stunned silence broken by screaming both full of fear and of outrage as the crowd stared at what Varatus had fashioned. And Varatus sreamed the loudest. He finally understood the images he had been seeing they were all parts of the statue. The gloved and thorned fist seemed to reach for the confessor, while the octupus head of the statue seemed to shout in triumph showing rows upon rows of shark teeth. That was all Veratus saw before his wits failed him and he slipped into unconciousness. But the crowd was less gentle and they pressed towards him intent on ripping him apart.
- The Seemings of the Deep Ones - Pt.1 Visions

TEXT.English:
It had been five days since Serrato had been seperated from his recon squad. He had tried to look for them, but since the supplies had run out weeks ago, his immediate survival needs had more often than not dictated the course he must take. If one ignored the mud and rockslide that had seperated him from the expedition, the treck had been blessedly uneventful, even quiet. And though plant life grew to enormous dimensions in this hidden valley he had yet to see a single large animal. There were insects and birds aplenty but not single mammal or amphibian bigger than a rat or a toad was in this jungle. Strangely though, there were paths in the jungle, whether they were old animal trails or paths that had been used and planned by humanoids he had not yet been able to decide. He was just now following such a path through enourmous ferns and groves of fresh bamboo grass. The jungle had become steadily quieter, not even a single bird could be heard anymore. Now that he concentrated on the absence of birdsong, he also realized that he could no longer hear a single insect. There was no "total" absence of sound he could still hear the leaves moving in the wind and the trees straining against their own weight. He moved an enormous fern that had grown into the path which enabled him to see a large clearing behind it, but at the same moment he became aware of hundreds of presences all around him. Serrato gripped his machete tighter and took two steps out into the clearing to get a better look at the enormous black and gold structure that rose before him.
"The souls capacity for generating positive, and negative, emotions is limitless. What I mean, is given sufficient stimuli and energy, a single soul can translate all the energy input into positive or negative emotions and thus into highly nutritious food for me and my kind. The primitive way to feed would be to harvest all the naturally acummulated emotions that can be found in a mortals soul."
Serrato ducked behind a near bush the cold emotionless voice he had thought to hear had scared him immensely. He took several deep breaths and tried to gather his wits again.
TO BE CONTINUED

TEXT.English:
'BOOM'
The great gates shuttered, the impact knocking the carpenters off balance as they furiously pounded in place an improvised barricade in a last, desperate attempt to support them.
'BOOM'
The wood in the doors began to splinter and bow inwards ominously, the drop bar keeping the gate shut bending in its frame. Korric's comrades shifted nervously on either side of him, one who was closest to the walls, absently brushed from his shoulder guards the dust shaken free from the masonry of the large stones beside him.
'BOOM'
Again the thunderous impact shook the gates, the cracks now formed on the masonry that framed the massive portal, fissures forming in the doors themselves where the lengths of oak from which they where made began to bend and pull apart from each other.
'BOOM'
Korric could sense the moral of his men begin to shake, not only from the blows that shook the stone around him, but also from the chanting that accompanied it.
"Khazad" "ROOT"
'BOOM'
"ROOT" "Dromie" "ROOT"
'BOOM'
"ROOT" "Atzobad" "ROOT"
'BOOM'
"ROOT" "Throne" "ROOT"
'BOOM'
The hammering blows continued until nearly one hundred men, all that remained of the defenders, stiffened as one.
'CRACK'
A blade thin fissure snapped across the stones above the gate, neatly bisecting the keystone and sending a fist sized chunk of stone from its apex sailing across the courtyard beyond. Korrek felt an icy knife of dread cut threw him.
'CRUNCH'
The workers, panicked now, scrambled away from the overstressed doors as a portion roughly the size of a large mans helmet shattered outwards. Dagger sized Splinters slicing into there arms and hands, brought up in a feeble attempt to protect themselves.
'CRUNCH - BOOM'
with a final explosion of wood and stone the great bar across the gates snapped in half as if a stick over a knee. What remained of the doors slamming open and into the walls beside them, the metal hinges tearing free from the stone as if set into moldy bread. Behind them stood row on row of shields as tall and broad as those that carried them. There was a moment of panicked silence, broken as the chant continued without pause. The first row of attackers marching in time to it against the volleys of arrows and stones that rebounded impotently against there shields. There footsteps where as drums of doom.
"ROOT"
"thump, thump"
"Khazad" "ROOT"
"thump, thump, thump"
Korrek's men surged forward like a flood onto the attackers, and where swept aside like waves on a mountainside. His men broke upon that wall of shields and spears, the body of the fallen trampled beneath the boots of the enemy.
"ROOT"
"thump, thump"
"Zamrat" "ROOT"
"thump, thump, thump"
The Dwarves of Khazad had come...

TEXT.English:
[A hilltop just before sundown strong winds tousle the hair and clothes of the gathered militia]
"As in the age of Ice when days were short and darkness everywhere--some have to take up the torch, and be guardians to their fellow men. We are not a nation of warriors, but artisans, poets, philosophers, farmers, millers and ranchers. Yet if all light is extinguished, all men are the same; for our base nature is that of beasts, and to that nature we would revert were it not for the grace and the light of Lugus. Today we pledge to be the flame of hope and the shield of burnished steel for our small settlement. We who have gathered here, take this oath, so that our brothers and sisters do not have to. And so that our friends and family can live a safe and enlightened existance."
[The commander stands quiet amongst his men waiting for the sunrise.]
"As the sun rises I pledge myself to begin my watch.
"There will be neither end nor pause to my vigil, for we are radiant in thought as well as in deed. I will not harbour secrets nor engage in falsehoods, for truth and light are one, just as darkness and lies.
"I will help my brothers see clearly by my light, and should the candle of my vigil flicker and fail I know that my brothers will stand in my place, so that darkness and shadows cannot pass.
"My place is not to seek out darkness, for those who seek it darken themselves; but to hold fast againse its encroachment and keep the horrors at bay.
- The Guardians Oath, heard on a hill near Innishboffin

We are not a nation of warriors, but artisans, poets, philosophers, farmers, millers and ranchers. Yet if all light is extinguished, all men are the same; for our base nature is that of beasts, and to that nature we would revert were it not for the grace and the light of Lugus. Today we pledge to be the flame of hope and the shield of burnished steel for our small settlement. We who have gathered here, take this oath, so that our brothers and sisters do not have to. And so that our friends and family can live a safe and enlightened existance."
[The commander stands quiet amongst his men waiting for the sunrise.]
"As the sun rises I pledge myself to begin my watch.
"There will be neither end nor pause to my vigil, for we are radiant in thought as well as in deed. I will not harbour secrets nor engage in falsehoods, for truth and light are one, just as darkness and lies.
"I will help my brothers see clearly by my light, and should the candle of my vigil flicker and fail I know that my brothers will stand in my place, so that darkness and shadows cannot pass.
"My place is not to seek out darkness, for those who seek it darken themselves; but to hold fast againse its encroachment and keep the horrors at bay.
- The Guardians Oath, heard on a hill near Innishboffin

TEXT.English:
He had gotten clean away. The millers daughter was dead and confessor Aldivatus did not even suspect him. But now it was time to leave the village and begin anew again. Secrets like his had a way of coming to light and he had to be away before the villagers suspected anything. Anette had been her name and she had been a sweet girl. And when she had smiled at him he had lost his lifelong fight against his inner deamons again. He had not meant to hurt her could barely remember her struggles against his workhardened body. But he remembered her crying afterwards, remembered she would not stop no matter what he said. So he killed her. He had hurried home then and begun to pack. No one thought it odd that he would go to town to buy supplies and confessor Aldivatus had even wished him a safe journey and a speedy return. Now he was well away and safe of all reprisals, or so he thought as a patrol of crusaders under the command of a cleric of Junil stopped him. They had no proof, they had not even suspicions all they had was the cleric claiming it was his face he had seen in a prophetic dream. And that someone would come looking for him soon. So they took him into custody waiting for the prophecised person to come. And sure enough after two days in the dark cells of a highway-guard tower confessor Aldivatus came for him. And when he was dragged back to the village to face Anettes family and to recieve judgement he begged Aldivatus for mercy, just as Anette had begged him. But all the confessor had to say was: "I do now know your soul so I cannot judge you with mercy else this might repeat itself. All I can dispense is justice. You will have to look for mercy from the gods."
-"The book of the path", Chapter III: Darkness

TEXT.English:
"There is a reason why most young summoners and indeed most established summoning schools start out by calling up nature spirits that can be found in the wilderness surrounding the caster every day. Usually we summoners do not start our careers at a whim. Very few of us wake up one morning saying: "It seems to be a slow day I´ll summon some yellow mice later on." No for most of us it is a lifethreatening situation that leads us to our summoning abilities . Usually we are being threatened by something horrible so we instinctively call upon the most terrible and most powerful being we can clearly envision. And for most of us, at the beginning of our careers this is the biggest local predator. Be it gigantic lupine or gigantic feline it does not matter much as long as it has claws and teeth and we can envision it clearly it will serve our purposes here. But what few young summoners realize is that those things are usually avoided for a reason and rarely called to ones side. Because what giant wolves and cats have in common is that they are almost always hungry. And so with the just finished invoation still ringing in our ears we now enter another challenge, the challenge of control. It is with this challenge that the ranks of prospective summoners begin to thin out for the consequences of failure are extreme. So let us examine the different ways of exerting control......"
- Introduction to basic summoning by Aeron Greywater

TEXT.English:
"So the meeting is over and in the end the decision was an easy one son. The other elders and me we reckoned that Beavercreek has all the makings of a rich fur trading town. So the council decided to, how did it go, what councilman Heapthrow the pompous bastard said, ah yes," ..... to forgo the usual petitions and burocatri, piurocratic, ah damn that red tape stuff the administrators keep talking about, and announce the first annual, that means it happens every harvest time, Beavercreek fur and commodities market." Which is what you and I are going to do now. The announcing I mean. No leave the bucket. So basically what we are to do is scream at people to visit the townsquare tomorrow for the big fair. VISIT THE AN UAL FUR MARKET. Like that see? Ah by the way son councilman Hethers told me he still needs a capable lad for gathering pure. Yes I know it stinks, but the money is nothing to sneeze at. They say good times are coming to Beavercreek son, we just have to hitch ourselves to the right wagon."
- Farmer Hayholt to his son Doln

TEXT.English:
"Are you serious? Turnips, again? Why the hell does the council insist on sending us turnips year after year? The great drought is now five years past yet they still keep on sending turnips." Assief leant against a clay wall still hot from the afternoon sun chewing tabacco and occasionally spitting unappetizing blobs on the tiled floor. He was supposed to be guarding the aid shipment but since no one could be bothered to steal it he was not a very attentive guard keeping his attention mostly on Musif who was unloading sack after sack of produce. After unloading the last sack from the first wagon Musif spit into his hands and started rubbing them. He hated unloading turnips he always felt they made his skin get brittle and dry. Well maybe it was the bags but he hated the labor nonetheless. Sighing he turned to Assief, "Seems a bit silly doesn´t it. But that is paper pushers for you. Hardly anybode lives here anymore and those who do need guns and swords more than food. If we did not store it all here it would probably get taken by orcish raiders the next day. And those Calabim night creatures, I doubt they´d take the turnips but food is not much good if there is no one around to eat it anymore. But they still sennd turnips to feed thirty- thousand people. I doubt that there ever were that many people in redsands province. Turnips for thirty thousand each month. And who is the lucky sod who gets to unload them........" Mumbling Musif went towards the next wagon to begin hi job anew while Assief followed him with a mischievous grin on his face. As Musif lifted the next sack from the wagonbed a seam ripped open and turnips rolled around in the courtyard of the granary. Musief cursed while his friend just laughed until a dry voice cut the laughter short. "You are right to curse. Your clumsiness just cost us a ramrod. Guns do not fire without ramrods. And a soldier whose gun does not fire while he stares at a charging oger........." "You must be mistaken Teutorix, those are just Turnips in these bags not guns." "As a nation we are forbidden by treaty to trade with the dwarves, but the dwarves just lost much of their farmland to the advancing veil forces and as you said before we need guns which the dwarves can provide. We are fomally at peace with the Vampires and the orcs although it is an uneasy peace at best, but the council cannot send weapons directly without threatening it. So the council sends us turnips purposefully forgetting to recount the population knowing full well that the nomads can exchange the turnips for guns with the dwarves. Take better care of my guns Musif."
-overheard in Sangralita, redsands province, two days before the battle in redrock gorge

Mumbling Musif went towards the next wagon to begin hi job anew while Assief followed him with a mischievous grin on his face. As Musif lifted the next sack from the wagonbed a seam ripped open and turnips rolled around in the courtyard of the granary. Musief cursed while his friend just laughed until a dry voice cut the laughter short. "You are right to curse. Your clumsiness just cost us a ramrod. Guns do not fire without ramrods. And a soldier whose gun does not fire while he stares at a charging oger........." "You must be mistaken Teutorix, those are just Turnips in these bags not guns." "As a nation we are forbidden by treaty to trade with the dwarves, but the dwarves just lost much of their farmland to the advancing veil forces and as you said before we need guns which the dwarves can provide. We are fomally at peace with the Vampires and the orcs although it is an uneasy peace at best, but the council cannot send weapons directly without threatening it. So the council sends us turnips purposefully forgetting to recount the population knowing full well that the nomads can exchange the turnips for guns with the dwarves. Take better care of my guns Musif."
-overheard in Sangralita, redsands province, two days before the battle in redrock gorge
TEXT.Spanish:
"Are you serious? Turnips, again? Why the hell does the council insist on sending us turnips year after year? The great drought is now five years past yet they still keep on sending turnips." Assief leant against a clay wall still hot from the afternoon sun chewing tabacco and occasionally spitting unappetizing blobs on the tiled floor. He was supposed to be guarding the aid shipment but since no one could be bothered to steal it he was not a very attentive guard keeping his attention mostly on Musif who was unloading sack after sack of produce. After unloading the last sack from the first wagon Musif spit into his hands and started rubbing them. He hated unloading turnips he always felt they made his skin get brittle and dry. Well maybe it was the bags but he hated the labor nonetheless. Sighing he turned to Assief, "Seems a bit silly doesn´t it. But that is paper pushers for you. Hardly anybode lives here anymore and those who do need guns and swords more than food. If we did not store it all here it would probably get taken by orcish raiders the next day.
