TEXT.English: At the Stag Camp, which is not just a place, but it is also an event for the Doviello Tribes. It is here where the Fathers teach their sons to hunt the Great Stag as well as other beasts of the forest and the tundra. And in this teaching are the foundations of their Hunter-Warrior society passed on from generation to generation. As long as their is wilderness, especially the cold wilderness, their will be the sons of Doviello.

TEXT.English: The smell of burnt flesh was the worst. All his childhood friends lay scattered around Herik partly burning in theat infernal substance the Balor had spit at their unit and their smell reminded him of last mornings bacon. Heriks captain had died last just a few minutes, or few eternities ago, shot in the belly by one of the crossbow bolts the enemy had been sending uphill through the whole ghastly battle. Now except for the sizzling sound the corpses around him made as they were roasted in their own juices with skins cracking and Heriks dry heaving everything was quiet on the hillside. It seemed as if the the slaughter done the hill had been forgotten by the enemy. In the halflight of dawn it seemed as if he was the only one left alive. The only survivor of a night of butchery and slaughter. Shaking his head as if denying the possibility of so much death being real Herik started to crawl away. Dowhill into the shadows and darkness that was the way to go he thought the way to safety there no horrors could be seen and the still air would not carry the appetizing smell of his friends cooked flesh. Gods he was hungry, and hurt, and tired. His lips had cracked from thirst so he kept looking around the desolation he was crawling through, looking for water. But all he saw was death and horror mutilated corpses, burnt soldiers friends and enemies alike, and perhaps worst the wounded no one cared for, they whipered or cried out from time to time, but after the chaos and cacophony of before it seemed dead quiet now. It was even quiet enough to hear a sharp snapping sound from the hilltop. As Herik looked up he saw in the light of a new dawn the banner of the fourth chapter proudly and defiantly being lifted by a battered young man. Then a weak cheer rolled across the hillside as the survivors saw the banner go up. And as the Flagbearer started signalling to regroup Herik turned around and started uphill again. He was not alone. They had held another night. All over the hillside other solders were climbing. Survivors like him, bloodied, tired, hungy and thirsty but alive. They would gather at the hilltop and Junil willing hold another night....... -Warstories, an autobiography of Herik Finstbruck

TEXT.English:
The positions at the ford were being overrun. The gaudily dressed carneval guards were falling back where they could, surrendering or dying on bannor pikes where they could not. Sparkling Top Hathad command of the archers on the ridge overlooking the ford. He had his men cease firing for now because the fighting was so closely packed now that there was no way to ensure their arrows would not hit their own desperatly battling men. While his fellow artists died at the ford Top Hat found time for reflection. Not yet twenty years ago the carneval had embarked on a mission to bring gaity and laughter to the oh so stern Bannor who languished in their self imposed steel cages of conformity. Now it looked as if the people of the great carneval would soon join the Bannor in their dreary cages. The fighting freaks and mimes were mostly dead or prisoners. Many of the knife throwers and arrow artists had lost their thumbs to the bannor and so would never throw or shoot for the delight of the crowd or the astonishment of an enemy again. Yes there had been pretty little to laugh at for Top Hat over the last few months. So he had sought consolation and gaity in the wine tents like many of his fellow troop directors.
He cut out of his musings when he realized the din and clamour of the fight by the ford was dying down. Soon it was again eerily quiet at the ford and so the shouts and the singing from the beast handler tents could be heard again. The last supplies of wine and liquor had gone to the beast handlers and Top Hat was at a loss to understand why. When the war had started to turn bad there had been repeated tries to use their elephants in battle and while they were excellent beasts of burden and their highly prized tusks made them formidable fighters in the arena, the inabilty to reliably control them on a battlefield had almost always led to a rout of the beasts. And they would trample any number of friendly soldiers to get away from the battle. Their other beasts, lions, tigers, giant spiders, dog sized cockroaches had all proven usefull in ambushes. They had been easy to use by the simple expedient of not having any troops nearby, but the elephants had always just run away. And now this most useless of units got all the alcohol the army had left........
Top Hat was not a man given to miserly behavior or jealosy but he was near to livid whenever he thought of those useless beasthandlers quaffing all the alcohol that was left while he and his men had to stand and die with barely a drop between them. And their loud capering and carousing could be heard all the way from their camp to his position so it was hardly possible to avoid thinking about them.
"Sir, Hat, Sir!" one of the sentries called from a place further down the slope. Top Hat swaggered towards him. " Report private Fizzy Sludge." "The enemy is forming up again, readying to advance, sir!" His need for a drink forgotten Top Hat hurried back to the center of his line calling out orders: "Spikemen form up! I want two of your squares as breakwaters. Hold and funnel them. I want the enemy only able to charge up the center of the ridge! Give our archers time to shoot! Tubas sound the stand to!" Jolly oomphing marching music accompanied him as he went on giving orders. He and his 6000 archers and mixed infantry were the last force between the unsmiling Bannor army and Jubilee the eternal carneval. And although he was outnumbered six to one he did not intend to give his beloved city to the enemy without a fight. No joke, he would bleed them, bleed them like a Calabim princeling. And what a fine way to face the end Top Hat thought. The jolly polka his tubas played as a call to stand to was acompanied by the jarring and arrythmic clanging of the spikemens´ bands, and the high pitched ringing of the NCOs bells of rank.
"I need your men to fire flaming arrows into the grass at the foot of the ridge, Sparkles." His reverie rudely interrupted Sparkling Top Hat turned around to see Yellow Groin Strap casually sauntering towards him. Top Hat opened his mouth to tell the insufferable man, he commanded the beast handlers, to go entertain Hyborem, but Groin Strap spoke first. "Don´t just stand there gaping man! I need your fire arrows at the foot of the ridge else my boys will go charging of Perpentach knows where." Still trying to make sense of the of the order, who the hell is going to charge the Bannor and why do they need fire arrows shot in to the damp grass, Top Hat decided to go along. "Archers ignite arrows!" The hooting and laughing from the beast handler camp seemed to draw closer and amidst the shouts he could also here the terrified trumpeting of elephants. What the hell it was his last stand anyways. "Aim at the foot of the ridge boys!" He saw enormous dark shaps running in front of a line of beast handlers making straight for the flat plain between his ridge and the ford, right where the Bannor assault troops were massing. And then he understood what groin strap was doing. "Aim low boys do not shoot the Bannor shoot the grass at the foot of the hill. Shoot low! Aaaaaand lose!" Panicked and drunk boxed in by fire the only way the elephants could go was towards the ford, towards the Bannor. Where they normally would have turned and run as soon as the Pikes stabbed at them, they now grew enraged and charged the men stabbing at them spearing amen with their tusks and trampling them underfoot. For Top Hat watching from the hill it was a glorious sight. He kept his archers firing flaming arrows inching forward. driving the elephants before his barrage of fire. Until the Bannor broke and the Belseraph charged down from their ridge it was the Bannors´ turn to die............
Alone on the hill Yellow Groin Strap whistled a melody. He chuckled. "As always guidance is much more effective than control."
-Phantasms in colour, Heroes on Jubilee hill, Performed by three coin candle

TEXT.English: Harron had left the trees of the Harthorne woods behind months ago, yet whenever he closed his eyes trying to find the peace sleep brings, he was back there. His horses flanks were shaking and wet from fear and exhaustion. The eyes open wide as phantoms raced along the uneven forest track by night. The sounds of hooves were all around them as the other riders of the emberlance mercenary units galloped on in heedless flight. The sounds of hooves on forest floor and heavy breathing, broken by a scream of pain when a horse went down due to their reckless flight across ground strewn with obstacles. Everyone would gallop on ignoring their fallen comrade and his horse except perhaps only to steer around him so as to not to share his fate. And every time one of them went down and was swallowed by the shadows of the forest, a scream of terror would erupt and then change to one of excruciating pain, could be heard shortly afterwards as the dark kin dispatched those who failed to keep up. Pictures would flash through Harron's mind as he sought for sleep in vain. A dark forest, the moon seemingly the color of blood. Riding through a ravine at full gallop, looking up and seeing his captain strung up across the ravine, still alive still breathing, the dripping blood leaving a metallic tang in his gaping mouth. Corporal Dannon slowing down. His words "I think we lost them.", followed by the sight of an arrow sticking out of his left eye. Panicked flight again. Fewer men around him perhaps twenty. Harding's horse collapsing at a ford and Harding begging to be allowed to ride with someone else. Nobody was willing to take him so Harding jumped at Marksin and fell back down with Marksin's knife in his throat. A roar sent the horses scattering. Corporal Mercher hit something galloping ahead, Mercher's severed head sailed by, panic fixed on his face as Harron ducked under the wire that had decapitated Marksin. No rest, arrows from every bush. A large clearing in the shadow of an enormous oak. Survivors starting to rein in. A roar from above followed by arrows. An arrow sticking in his right shoulder. The poison burning its way through him. Clutching his horse. And then blackness. They called Harron a survivor. The survivor would be more appropriate because he was the only one. But tonight was different. The others were joking after all the Svarts were beaten, their cavalry had fled to the woods the plains were taken. Tomorrow the army would follow them back into Hawthorne. The army but not Harron, the survivor because he lay in his tent his wrist cut open closing his eyes to finally find peace. - The dangers of the Elderfolk, Simion Coldvein

The army but not Harron, the survivor because he lay in his tent his wrist cut open closing his eyes to finally find peace. - The dangers of the Elderfolk, Simion Coldvein
TEXT.Italian: Harron had left the trees of the Harthorne woods behind months ago, yet whenever he closed his eyes trying to find the peace sleep brings, he was back there. His horses flanks were shaking and wet from fear and exhaustion. The eyes open wide as phantoms raced along the uneven forest track by night. The sounds of hooves were all around them as the other riders of the emberlance mercenary units galloped on in heedless flight. The sounds of hooves on forest floor and heavy breathing, broken by a scream of pain when a horse went down due to their reckless flight across ground strewn with obstacles. Everyone would gallop on ignoring their fallen comrade and his horse except perhaps only to steer around him so as to not to share his fate. And every time one of them went down and was swallowed by the shadows of the forest, a scream of terror would erupt and then change to one of excruciating pain, could be heard shortly afterwards as the dark kin dispatched those who failed to keep up. Pictures would flash through Harron's mind as he sought for sleep in vain. A dark forest, the moon seemingly the color of blood. Riding through a ravine at full gallop, looking up and seeing his captain strung up across the ravine, still alive still breathing, the dripping blood leaving a metallic tang in his gaping mouth. Corporal Dannon slowing down. His words "I think we lost them.", followed by the sight of an arrow sticking out of his left eye. Panicked flight again. Fewer men around him perhaps twenty. Harding's horse collapsing at a ford and Harding begging to be allowed to ride with someone else. Nobody was willing to take him so Harding jumped at Marksin and fell back down with Marksin's knife in his throat. A roar sent the horses scattering. Corporal Mercher hit something galloping ahead, Mercher's severed head sailed by, panic fixed on his face as Harron ducked under the wire that had decapitated Marksin. No rest, arrows from every bush. A large clearing in the shadow of an enormous oak. Survivors starting to rein in. A roar from above followed by arrows. An arrow sticking in his right shoulder. The poison burning its way through him. Clutching his horse. And then blackness. They called Harron a survivor. The survivor would be more appropriate because he was the only one. But tonight was different. The others were joking after all the Svarts were beaten, their cavalry had fled to the woods the plains were taken. Tomorrow the army would follow them back into Hawthorne. The army but not Harron, the survivor because he lay in his tent his wrist cut open closing his eyes to finally find peace. - The dangers of the Elderfolk, Simion Coldvein

"We are the lumberjacks of Eldervale, and we cut down trees without fear nor fail, neither ork nor elf nor treant nor drake, nothing is stopping us. We keep the sawmills running as long as the forest lasts."
-Song of the lumberjack, sung until the opening of the Eldervale portal
